Phase 3 - Nimotuzumab in Pancreatic Canc:
Original Reports |Gastrointestinal Cancer
Nimotuzumab Plus Gemcitabine for K-Ras Wild-Type Locally
Advanced or Metastatic Pancreatic Cancer
Shukui Qin, MD1; Jin Li, MD2; Yuxian Bai, MD, PhD3; Zishu Wang, MD4; Zhendong Chen, MD, PhD5; Ruihua Xu, MD, PhD6;
Jianming Xu, MD7; Hongmei Zhang, MD8; Jia Chen, MD9; Ying Yuan, MD10; Tianshu Liu, MD11; Lin Yang, MD, PhD12; Haijun Zhong, MD13;
Donghui Chen, MD14; Lin Shen, MD, PhD15; Chunyi Hao, MD, PhD15; Deliang Fu, MD, PhD16; Ying Cheng, MD17; Jianwei Yang, MD18;
Qiong Wang, MD19; Baoli Qin, MD20; Hongming Pan, MD21; Jun Zhang, MD, PhD22; Xianhong Bai, MD23; and Qingshan Zheng, MD, PhD24
DOI https://doi.org/10.1200/JCO.22.02630
ABSTRACT
PURPOSE In a phase IIb trial of nimotuzumab plus gemcitabine, substantial clinical
beneﬁts were observed in patients with locally advanced or metastatic pan-
creatic cancer (PC). Therefore, we conducted a phase III clinical study to verify
the efﬁcacy and safety of this combination regimen in patients with K-Ras wild-
type tumors (ClinicalTrials.gov identi ﬁer:NCT02395016 ).
PATIENTS AND
METHODSEligible patients were randomly assigned to receive nimotuzumab (400 mg
once per week) or placebo followed by gemcitabine (1,000 mg/m2on days 1, 8,
and 15, once every 4 weeks) until disease progression or unacceptable toxicity.
The primary end point was overall survival (OS) and the secondary end pointswere progression-free survival (PFS), response rates, and safety.
RESULTS A total of 480 patients were screened; 92 patients were enrolled and 82 patients
with K-Ras wild-type tumors were eligible. In the full analysis set, the median
OS was 10.9 versus 8.5 months, while the restricted mean survival time (RMST)was 18.05 versus 11.14 months for the investigational versus control arm (ratioof control vinvestigation 50.62 [0.40-0.97]; P5.036). Median PFS was 4.2
versus 3.6 months in the investigational versus control arm (log-rank P5.04;
hazard ratio, 0.60 [0.37-0.99]) and the restricted mean PFS time was 8.08versus 4.76 months (RMST ratio, 0.58 [0.38-0.90]; P5.036). Both OS and PFS
were longer in the nimotuzumab group than in the placebo group. The objective
response rates and disease control rates were 7% versus 10% and 68% versus
63% for the investigational and control groups, respectively. The incidence ofadverse events were comparable between the two groups.
CONCLUSION In patients with locally advanced or metastatic K-Ras wild-type PC, nimotu-
zumab plus gemcitabine signi ﬁcantly improved OS and PFS with a good safety
proﬁle.
INTRODUCTION
Pancreatic cancer (PC) is a common and fatal malignancy
that occurs worldwide. Eighty percent of PC cases are di-
agnosed as advanced or metastatic stage.1Twenty- ﬁve
percent of patients with advanced PC are at a locally ad-vanced stage, with a median overall survival (mOS) of6-9 months. Approximately 60%-70% of patients withadvanced PC are at the metastatic stage, with mOS of only3-5 months.
2–9Unfortunately, the current regimens are
unsatisfactory. Encouraging the achievement of new reg-imens has been developed in many other cancer ﬁelds but
rarely in PC. Therefore, there is an urgent need for effective
therapies to prolong the survival of patients with PC.Nimotuzumab is a recombinant humanized monoclonal
antibody against the epidermal growth factor receptor(EGFR). A phase IIb study (PCS07) done in Germany showedthat nimotuzumab plus gemcitabine might signi ﬁcantly
improve the mOS (8.6 months v6.0 months) of locally ad-
vanced or metastatic PC, especially for the wild-type K-Rasgene subgroup (11.62 months v5.67 months; 1-year survival
rates, 53.8% v15.8%, respectively).
10In 2014, gemcitabine was
widely used and was considered the standard of care for ﬁrst-
line treatment regimen for patients with advanced PC inChina. Thus, we conducted a phase III trial (NOTABLE study)to verify the ef ﬁcacy and safety of nimotuzumab plus gem-
citabine as ﬁrst-line treatment for patients with locally ad-
vanced or metastatic PC.ACCOMPANYING CONTENT

PATIENTS AND METHODS
Study Oversight
The NOTABLE study was approved by each institution ’s
independent ethics committee, the Chinese Drug RegulatoryAuthority, and the National Medical Products Administra-tion, adhering to the Helsinki Declaration on human medical
research.
11
The investigators and autho rs designed the Protocol
(online only) using a sponsor (Biotech Pharmaceutical Co,
Ltd). The principal investigators from each site adhered to
the study protocol. In addition, data were collected andanalyzed by professional third-party statisticians who cer-tiﬁed the accuracy and completeness of the reported data.
Patents
Patients with locally advanced or metastatic PC were
screened. Each patient signed an informed consent form
before screening. Eligible patients were age 18-75 yearswith histologically con ﬁrmed locally advanced/metastatic
P Cw i t ht h eK - R a sw i l d - t y p eg e n e( S a n g e rg e n es e q u e n c e ) .Other inclusion criteria we re a Karnofsky performance
status (KPS) score ≥60, ineligibility for radical radio-
therapy or surgery, previou sa d j u v a n tc h e m o t h e r a p y
(if any) for more than 6 months before enrollment, at least
one measurable lesion (RECIST 1.1),
12and an estimated life
expectancy of 12 weeks or more, together with normalorgan function.
Study Design and Treatment
This was a prospective, multicenter, randomized, double-blinded, phase III clinical study (NOTABLE study), in which
eligible patients were randomly assigned (1:1) to receiveintravenous nimotuzumab (400 mg) or a placebo once a week.
Gemcitabine (1,000 mg/m
2) was administered intravenously
once per week (on days 1, 8, and 15) for 3 weeks, rest for 1 week,then once per week for 4 weeks for one treatment cycle.Treatment was continued until disease progression, unman-ageable toxicity, or withdrawal of consent was observed. Thepatients were followed up until death or study completion.
Patients were strati ﬁed by tumor localization (head, body, or
tail of the pancreas) according to previous surgery, history ofbiliary obstruction treatment, and adjuvant chemotherapy.
Assessments
The investigators evaluated t he tumor response via computed
tomography or magnetic resonance imaging scan every8 weeks, according to RECIST ver sion 1.1. The clinical bene ﬁt
response (CBR) was evaluated every 8 weeks on the basis of theBurris criteria.
13Adverse events (AEs) and serious adverse
events were monitored by the investigators from the beginningof the treatment and up to 30 days after treatment completion.
The detected events were graded according to the Common
Terminology Criteria for Adverse Events, version 4.03,
14and
coded and summarized according to the preferred terms in theMedical Dictionary for Regulato ry Activities, version 24.0.
Study End Points
The primary end point was overall survival (OS), de ﬁned as
the time from random assignment to death due to anycause. Subgroup analyses of OS were based on prespeci ﬁed
stratiﬁcation factors. The secondary end points were
progression-free survival (PFS), de ﬁned as the time from
random assignment until objective tumor progression ordeath; time to progression (TTP, de ﬁned as the time from
random assignment until objective tumor progression);objective response rate (ORR), including complete responseCONTEXT
Key Objective
Does nimotuzumab (a humanized epithelial growth factor receptor monoclonal antibody) plus gemcitabine regimen provide
an overall survival (OS) bene ﬁt for patients with locally advanced or metastatic K-Ras wild-type pancreatic cancer (PC)?
Knowledge Generated
In a multicenter, randomized, double-blinded, phase III clinical trial in China, patients with locally advanced or metastaticK-Ras wild-type PC were enrolled. The results showed that nimotuzumab plus gemcitabine signi ﬁcantly improved OS and
progression-free survival with a good safety pro ﬁle compared with the placebo-gemcitabine group.
Relevance (E.M. O ’Reilly)
This randomized trial con ﬁrms that identi ﬁcation of KRAS wild-type PC is clinically important and therapeutically relevant
and can be successfully targeted.*
*Relevance section written by JCOAssociate Editor Eileen M. O ’Reilly, MD.

(CR) and partial response (PR); disease control rate (DCR),
including CR, PR, and stable disease; and CBR on the basis ofchanges in pain, KPS, and wei ght. Treatment-related ad-
verse events (TRAEs) were de ﬁned as adverse drug reac-
tions (ADRs).
Statistical Analysis
The primary end point was evaluated in the full analysis set(FAS; all eligible patients who received at least one dose ofnimotuzumab and had one evaluation of ef ﬁcacy). Secondary
end points were analyzed only in the FAS. A prespeci ﬁed
subgroup analysis of OS and PFS was performed using theFAS. Safety analysis was performed using the safety analysisset (SS; patients received at least one antibody dose).
Statistical analyses were performed using the SAS version
9.4 (SAS Institute, Cary, NC). OS was the primary ef ﬁcacy
end point and was analyzed using the Kaplan-Meier
method and strati ﬁed log-rank test. If the proportional
hazards assumption was unsatisfactory (eg, survival curvecrossover), the restricted mean survival time (RMST)model
15was used to analyze the survival bene ﬁt differ-
ence. RMST is suggested as a novel alternative measure insurvival analyses and may be us eful when the proportional
hazards assumption cannot be made. A right-censored
p a t t e r nw a su s e df o rt h eO Sd a t a .T h et i m ep o i n to ft h e
RMST model was the closest to the end of the trial.
We calculated that, with a sample of 276 patients, the study
would have 80% power to detect a hazard ratio (HR) fordeath with nimotuzumab plus gemcitabine (investigationalarm, or nimotuzumab-gemcitabine) versus placebo plusgemcitabine (control arm, or placebo-gemcitabine) of 0.69.
This estimation was based on the results of the full pop-
ulation in the PCS07 study, where the median OS of thegemcitabine monotherapy group was 6 months and themedian OS of the investigational arm was 8.7 months. Sincepatients with K-Ras wild-type PC were rare and recruitmentwas dif ﬁcult, we calculated that with a sample of 79 patients
and 64 events, the study would have 80% power to detecta HR for death with nimotuzumab-gemcitabine versus
placebo-gemcitabine. This assumption was made on the
basis of the result of patients with K-Ras wild-type PC inPCS07 study, where the median OS of gemcitabine mono-therapy group was 5.67 months, and the median survival ofthe investigational group was 11.62 months. The sample sizere-estimation was approved by the Chinese regulatory au-thorities. At the time of approval, 92 patients were enrolledand the study was terminated.
Multivariate analysis of survival data was conducted using
the Cox proportional hazard model according to prespeci ﬁed
stratiﬁcation factors to evaluate the treatment effect. In
addition to the HR as a measurement of the relative risk of anevent, the RMST ratio between arms (control vinvestigation)
was estimated after adjusting for covariates. For this anal-
ysis, a ratio of <1 indicated survival improvement in theinvestigational arm. Unlike the HR, the RMST ratio does not
rely on any model assumption.
16
The ORR was analyzed using the Fisher test, while the DCRand CBR were evaluated using the chi-squared test. AEs wereclassiﬁed according to the system organ class, preferred
term, or severity grade.
RESULTS
Patients and Treatment Groups
A total of 480 patients from 25 study sites in China werescreened between April 2015 and March 2021. Then, 92patients with the K-Ras wild-type gene were eligible for
random assignment, and 90 patients were allocated for
treatment. Eight patients who did not have K-Ras wild-typetumors according to a gene con ﬁrmatory procedure (seven
cases) or PC (one gallbladder carcinoma case), detectedduring monitoring, were excluded. Finally, 82 patients wereanalyzed as part of the FAS, and 41 were included in eachgroup. The FAS group was the modi ﬁed intent-to-treat
group ( Fig 1 ).
The demographic and clinical characteristics at baseline
were well balanced between the two groups ( Table 1 ).
Efﬁcacy
OS
The OS analysis was based on 76 deaths, including 36 deaths
in the nimotuzumab-gemcitabine group and 40 deaths in theplacebo-gemcitabine group. The mean follow-up time was57.6 months and 16.6 months, respectively, for the two
groups. The data cutoff was January 27, 2022. The median OS
was 10.9 months (95% CI, 5.6 to 16.3) in the nimotuzumab-gemcitabine group and 8.5 months (95% CI, 5.7 to 10.0) in theplacebo-gemcitabine group (Cox proportional HR, 0.66; 95%CI, 0.42 to 1.05; log-rank P5.08;Fig 2A ). When using RMST
model, the RMST was 18.05 months (95% CI, 11.71 to 24.38) inthe nimotuzumab-gemcitabine group and 11.14 months (95%CI, 8.07 to 14.20) in the placebo-gemcitabine group (RMST
ratio of control vtreatment, 0.62; 95% CI, 0.40 to 0.97;
P5.036; Table 2 ). OS was signi ﬁcantly longer in the
nimotuzumab-gemcitabine group ( Fig 2C ).
PFS and TTP
PFS was signi ﬁcantly longer in the nimotuzumab-gemcitabine
group than in the placebo-gemcitabine group, with mediansurvival time of 4.2 months (95% CI, 2.7 to 7.3) versus3.6 months (95% CI, 2.0 to 5.0; HR, 0.60; 95% CI, 0.37 to0.99; log-rank P5.04), respectively ( Fig 2B ). At a follow-
up of 31 months, the restricted mean PFS time was8.08 months (95% CI, 5.20 to 10.94) in the nimotuzumab-gemcitabine group and 4.76 months (95% CI, 3.41 to 6.09)
in the placebo-gemcitabine group (RMST ratio, 0.58;

The median TTP was 4.7 months (95% CI, 2.7 to 9.0) in the
nimotuzumab-gemcitabine group and 3.7 months (95% CI,2.0 to 5.4) in the placebo-gemcitabine group (HR, 0.67; 95%CI, 0.39 to 1.15; log-rank P5.311) of no signi ﬁcant difference.
ORR and DCR
ORRs were 7.3% (95% CI, 1.5 to 19.9) versus 9.8% (95% CI,
2.7 to 23.1) in the investigational versus control group, andthe DCRs were 68.3% (95% CI, 51.9 to 81.9) versus 63.4%(95% CI, 46.9 to 77.9), respectively. The ORR and DCR results
were not signi ﬁcantly different between the two groups.
CBR
The CBRs in the nimotuzumab-gemcitabine and placebo-
gemcitabine groups were 39.3% (95% CI, 21.2 to 57.4) and32.2% (95% CI, 15.8 to 48.8), respectively. However, this
difference was not statistically signi ﬁcant.
Subgroup Analyses
In the prespeci ﬁed subgroups, the results were mostly con-
sistent with the pooled results. Compared with the placebo-gemcitabine group, the nimotuzumab-gemcitabine groupshowed trends of larger survival as well as progression risk
reduction in several subgroups, especially for patients without
previous biliary obstruction (OS, 11.9 months v8.4 months;
HR, 0.54; 95% CI, 0.33 to 0.89; log-rank P5.035; PFS,
5.5 months v3.4 months; HR, 0.5; 95% CI, 0.29 to 0.85;
log-rank P5.035; Figs 3A and3B).

DISCUSSION
This prospective, randomized , controlled, double-blind,
multicenter clinical trial demonstrated that nimotuzumabcombined with gemcitabine prolonged the median OS time
by 2.4 months and decreased the mortality risk by 34%compared with the placebo gr oup by Cox regression. Once
the trial was completed, we observed that the survivalcurves overlapped until 6 months and gradually separatedthereafter. In this situation , the proportional hazard as-
sumption for the Cox regression model does not hold.
Consequently, it is not a robust method. Subsequently, weused the RMST model to calculate the survival differencesbetween the two curves using the RMST ratio, which behavesas an analog of the Cox proportional HR. The mortality riskdecreased by 38%, which was equivalent to RMST ratio 0.62(0.40-0.97) calculated at the placebo-gemcitabine versusnimotuzumab-gemcitabine direction, and the differences
were statistically signi ﬁcant. The RMST for both OS and PFS
was signi ﬁcantly longer in the nimotuzumab-gemcitabine
group than in the control group. The 1-year and 3-year OSrates were 43.6% versus 26.8% and 13.9% versus 2.7% inthe investigational and control arms, respectively. Theseresults demonstrated that nimotuzumab increased the0 6 12 18 24 30 36 42 48 54 60 66 72 7820406080100

gemcitabine group. The 95% CI for response-rate ratios was calculated according to the asymptotic 95% CI of the relative risk in the nimotuzumab-
gemcitabine group compared with the placebo-gemcitabine group. The RMST ratio was 0.62 (0.40-0.97) calculated at the placebo-gemcitabine
versus nimotuzumab-gemcitabine direction.
bPvalue was from the log-rank test of four strati ﬁed factors according to the tumor lesion site, surgery history, biliary obstruction treatment, and
adjuvant chemotherapy.
cObjective response included con ﬁrmed CR and PR.
dDisease control included con ﬁrmed CR, con ﬁrmed PR, and SD.

median survival time of patients with advanced PC with

Compared with other studies, the NOTABLE trial showed
that nimotuzumab might confer a remarkable survivalbeneﬁt. In a previous study, the median OS of gemcitabine
monotherapy was 5.65 months.
13However, the median OS
was increased to 6.24 months when combined with
erlotinib,17and 8.5 months and 1-year OS rate of 35%
when albumin-paclitaxel was added to gemcitabine.18In
addition to these regimens, the ﬂuorouracil, leucovorin,
irinotecan, and oxaliplatin (FOLFIRINOX) schedulehad the longest median survival time of 11.1 months;its usage is limited owing to side effects.
19Compared
with the current treatment alternatives, the medianOS of nimotuzumab-gemcit abine in this study was
10.9 months, and the 1-year OS rate was 43.6%, which was
equal to that of the FOLFIRINOX regimen, but with abetter safety pro ﬁle.PFS was also signi ﬁcantly higher in the nimotuzumab arm,
according to the log-rank Pvalue and RMST method. The
ORRs of the two treatment groups were similar; however, the
DCR and CBR were higher in the nimotuzumab group, al-
though the difference was not statistically signi ﬁcant. These
results indicate that nimotuzumab may improve diseasecontrol and slow the progression of advanced PC.
In the subgroup analyses, the nimotuzumab-gemcitabine
combination showed a greater bene ﬁt, which was consis-
tent with the results of the total population analysis. Thesubgroup analysis should be interpreted with caution be-cause after adjusting the sample size, the subgroups weresmall. Regarding the safety pro ﬁle, AEs or ADRs were
comparable between the two groups and did not increaseafter the addition of nimotuzumab. The frequency of total
hematologic or nonhematologic AEs (including grade
3 AEs) >10% was similar betwe en the two groups. All TRAEs
were grade 1-3, and no grade 4-5 adverse reactions or

events occurred. Only grade 1-2 rash reactions were ob-
served. This trial con ﬁrmed that nimotuzumab has a good
safety pro ﬁle.
The proportion of K-Ras wild-type tumors in our study was
17.1%. This percentage was higher than the internationallyreported data, but similar to a previous nationwide study in
China (16.8%).
20
One limitation of this study is that EGFR expression and other
genetic mutation types were not evaluated. It is unknownwhether patients with activation of the mitogen-activated
protein kinase pathway because of BRAF mutations would
beneﬁt from nimotuzumab treatment. Alternatively, other
kinase fusion genes might confer sensitivity to nimotuzumab.Delineating the molecular subtypes of K-Ras wild-type tu-
mors could improve patient selection for nimotuzumab
treatment.
Information on subsequent treatments after disease pro-
gression was not collected, whi ch is another limitation of
this study. Third, although there were no statistically
signiﬁcant differences in baseline c haracteristi cs between
the two arms, nimotuzumab-tre ated patients were slightly
younger and had a better performance status. These fea-
tures may have led to the improved treatment compliance.
Finally, the study protocol was formulated in 2014,
when the standard of care of ﬁrst-line treatment regimens
in China was gemcitabine monotherapy. At that time,

⚫Nimotuzumab combined with gemcitabine increases OS and PFS 
in patients with K -Ras wild -type locally advanced or metastatic 
pancreatic cancer, with an obvious good safety profile.
⚫NOTABLE study showed a breakthrough in treatment of advanced 
pancreatic cancer.

provide benefit and great value to pancreatic cancer patients.

CIMa Her  
nimotuzumab 50 mg

CIMa Her  
nimotuzumab 50 mg
Background: 
Existing treatment options including gemcitabine -based therapy and 5FU -based 
chemotherapy have limited prognostic impact in advanced pancreatic cancer (APC): the 
median overall survival ( mOS ) was 6 -11 months for 1st line therapy and 4 -9 months for 2nd 
line therapy.
Nimotuzumab ( nimo ), anti -EGFR monoclonal antibody, had been shown to be more effective 
against APC in two previous studies, PCS07 (a phase II study in Germany) and NOTABLE 
study (a phase III study in China). 
Although the NOTABLE study obtained an encouraging result in China, it focused on a 
narrow population, KRAS wild -type patients. 
This study aimed to explore the efficacy and safety of nimo  in the real -world population with 
APC. 
CIMa Her  
nimotuzumab 50 mg
Methods: 
In this retrospective observational study, patients with APC were treated with nimo  and 
followed up in a real -world clinical setting.
Demographic and clinical data of these patients were collected from electronic medical 
records of First Affiliated Hospital of Xi’an Jiaotong  University from April 2018 to June 
2022. 
The primary efficacy endpoint was overall survival.
CIMa Her  
nimotuzumab 50 mg
Results:
A total of 104 patients (median age was 60.5 years, range 34 -84) treated with nimo  and chemotherapy were analyzed. 
Among them, 11 (10.6%) were in stage II (AJCC 8th edition), 23 (22.1%) were in stage III, and 70(67.3%) were in stage IV. 
The treatment regimen included gemcitabine plus nab -paclitaxel (AG, 80.77%), gemcitabine plus S -1 (GS, 10.58%) and others. 
The dosage of nimo  was 200 -400mg weekly, of which above 50% of patients received nimo  400 mg weekly. 
About 66 (63.5%) patients received nimo  as 1st line therapy and 38 (36.5%) patients as 2nd line therapy. 
Up to July 5, 2022, the median follow -up time was 8.12 months and the mOS  was not reached.
The 1 -year and 2 - year OS rate were 80.2% and 74.4%, respectively. 
Further subgroup analysis showed that the mOS  was also not reached in 1st line treatment of nimo  (median follow -up time 
8.77 months) as well as the 2nd line treatment of nimo  (median follow -up time 7.62 months), showing a potential survival 
benefit. No grade 3 or above toxicities were observed. 
CIMa Her  
nimotuzumab 50 mg
Conclusions:
AG regimen was the most common therapy in clinical practice in China. The real - 
world study displayed the addition of nimo  would prolong the survival for APC, 
with a good safety profile. 
CIMa Her  
nimotuzumab 50 mg
Thank you

(Confidential Information )         1. OVERALL SUMMARY  
Knowledge of the epidermal growth factor receptor’s (EGFR) function in the malignant process 
has advanced enormously during the past decade. Its overexpression has been better characterized 
by different tumor  types but  also linked to a worse patient prognosis as well as radiotherapy and 
chemotherapy resistance. Additionally, the EGFR signaling pathway is known to contribute to 
several tumorigenic processes such as tumor  proliferation, apoptosis resistance, angiogenesis, 
invasion and metastasis. Therefore, t he EGFR receptor was identified as a promising therapeutic 
target and several therapeutic drugs, such as EGFR -directed tyrosine kinase inhibitors (TKIs) and 
anti-EGFR monoclonal antibodies (mAbs), have been developed in different malignancies. 
Although the  benefit of TKIs in association with chemotherapy remains to be seen, anti -EGFR 
mAbs display marked results in combination with both chemotherapy and radiotherapy. However, 
most of  these agents are commonly associated with a skin toxicity that appears as, among other 
things, an acneiform rash, skin dryness and nail changes that can be severe and adversely affect 
quality of life.  Current knowledge has led to the belief that this tox icity of the EGFR inhibitor 
class (i.e rash) is a hallmark of activity.  
Nimotuzumab is a recombinant monoclonal antibody directed against the human EGFR for use 
as monotherapy and in combination with radiation therapy and/or chemotherapy for the treatment 
of malignant diseases.  Nimotuzumab is alternatively referred to as TheraCIM h -R3, Theraloc®, 
CIMAher®, BIOMAb®-EGFR, Tai Xin Sheng®, OSAG -101, YMB -1000; or DE -766 however, 
nimotuzumab will be used throughout the Investigator’s Brochure.  
Nimotuzumab recognizes the human EGFR, thereby blocking the binding of its ligands and 
inducing inhibition of cell proliferation, pro -apoptotic signals, ADCC, CDC, and decreasing 
VEGF production. Nimotuzumab’s capacity to bind EGFR, in contrast with other anti-EGFR 
mAbs, is heavily dictated by cell receptor density. While it has similar preclinical and clinical 
activity when compared to other anti -EGFR mAbs in certain indications, it has one major 
difference: lack of severe skin toxicity as well as severe h ypomagnesemia and gastrointestinal 
adverse events. It is hypothesized that due to differences in its binding properties, nimotuzumab’s 
activity is mechanistically different from the other mAbs. It has been shown preclinically that in 
situations where EGFR density is low, like skin, the mAbs rely on one arm to bind to the EGFR 
epitope and cause its effect (monovalent binding). The level of EGFR blockade achieved is 
determined by the antibody’s specific binding affinity. In situations where receptor density i s high, 
as in certain tumors, mAb binding occurs via both arms (bivalent binding). Bivalent binding results 
in the formation of more stable bonds since it is dictated by the antibody’s avidity of binding as 
opposed to its binding affinity. Unlike  cetuximab and panitumumab, nimotuzumab binding has 
been shown to be highly dependent on EGFR density, binding only transiently in conditions of 
low EGFR density , while achieves  an accumulation pattern like cetuximab and panitumumab in 
conditions of high EGFR densit y. This observation suggests that nimotuzumab relies on bivalent 
binding for effective EGFR blockade, allowing nimotuzumab to bind robustly in tumors,  
overexpressing EGFR while sparing low EGFR -expressing normal tissue, thereby avoiding 
unwanted toxicities.  
A comprehensive battery of pharmacological testing has been performed with nimotuzumab. 
In vitro  binding assays have shown that nimotuzumab has high affinity binding to human lung 
adenocarcinoma, breast and vulvar epidermoid carcinomas and specifically recognize  
EGFR/HER -1 but not HER -2, HER -3 or HER -4. Immunohistochemistry studies have 
demonstrated that nimotuzumab recognizes EGFR on a large number of epithelial tumor  tissues. 
This is an expected outcome as tumors of epithelial origin have high EGFR expres sion.  In vitro  
pharmacology studies have shown the potential for nimotuzumab to inhibit cell proliferation and 
act as a cytostatic agent.  In addition, in vitro  studies have demonstrated that nimotuzumab inhibits 
Nimotuzumab Investigator’s Brochure  Confidential  
Property of InnoCIMAb PTE LTD  Version 20.0

(Confidential Information )         EGF -dependent EGFR phosphorylation as well as increases the radiosensitivity of either NSCLC 
or glioma cell lines expressing high or moderate levels of EGFR.  
Nimotuzumab inhibited tumor growth and angiogenesis, and induced apoptosis in A431 human 
vulvar epidermoid carcinoma xenografts in SCID mice.  When administered in combination with 
radiotherapy, nimotuzumab significantly delayed tumor  growth, inhibited angiogenesis, reduced 
the tumor  proliferation index, increased the number of apoptotic cells and reduced the 
phosphorylation activity of the EGFR in NMRI mice implanted with U87 glioma xenografts.  The 
antibody has also shown the ability to decrease the freque ncy of the radio -resistant CD133+cancer 
stem cells population in U87MG xenografts, even when it is administered concomitant to 
radiotherapy. In vitro  experiments conducted in this tumor model suggest that colocalization of 
the EGFR and the CD133 marker on tumor cells would be responsible for this activity.  
The combination of nimotuzumab and radiation also inhibited tumor  growth in athymic mice 
implanted with H292 and Ma -1 xenografts which express high or moderate levels of EGFR.  In 
addition, the combination of CPT -11 plus nimotuzumab showed greater inhibition of tumor  growth 
in an athymic mice implanted with gastric GCIY xenografts compared to single agent 
administration.  
Nimotuzumab has also showing ability to kill EGFR+ cells by activating NK cells, stimulating 
the ADCC activity and to induce the expansion of EGFR specific T cells subpopulations in treated 
patients, su ggesting a potential role in the activation of cellular antitumor responses.  
No evidence of systemic drug - or treatment -related toxicity of nimotuzumab was observed in 
rats after repeated daily administration over a 14 -day period at a dose level up to 57.14 mg/kg, 
equivalent to approximately 10 -fold the proposed maximum clinical da ily dose of 400 mg.  Daily 
intravenous administration of nimotuzumab at a dose level of 0.85 mg/kg (equivalent to a 
cumulative dose of more than 2.5 -fold the maximum proposed single human therapeutic dose of 
400 mg) for 14 days in monkeys was associated wi th minimal toxicity. At dose levels up to 11.4 
mg/kg, there was no evidence of detrimental pharmacological or toxicological effects in monkeys.  
Repeated weekly intravenous administration of up to 50.00 mg/kg nimotuzumab (approximately 
8.75-fold the propos ed maximum clinical daily dose of 400 mg) for 26 weeks in monkeys was not 
associated with any significant toxicological findings or evidence of detrimental pharmacological 
effects.

2. INTRODUCTION  
Nimotuzumab is a humanized monoclonal antibody targeting the Epidermal Growth Factor 
Receptor (EGFR), a key target in the development of cancer therapeutics.  EGFR targeting drugs 
have been shown to improve response when used with conventional treatments s uch as radiation 
therapy and chemotherapy.  EGFR (HER -1, erbB1) is a transmembrane glycoprotein and a 
member of the erbB family of receptors, which includes HER -2 (erbB2), HER -3, and HER -4.  
EGFR is activated by ligand binding, resulting in homo - or hetero -dimerization and the activation 
of tyrosine kinases, thereby activating downstream mitogenic activators. EGFR is a normal 
epithelial cell surface receptor, which is particularly active in tissues such as the epithelial lining 
of the gastrointestinal tract  and in skin follicles.  However, there is well -documented evidence that 
up-regulation of the EGFR signal transduction pathway is involved in the establishment and spread 
of tumor s of epithelial cell origin (Brabender 2001; Nicholson 2001).  Thus, agents t hat bind to 
and inhibit EGFR dimerization would be expected to exert antagonistic biological activity ( e.g., 
growth inhibition of cells requiring these ligands for proliferation).  
EGFR is over -expressed in a wide variety of human tumor s, including non -small cell lung 
(Brabender 2001; Nicholson 2001), astrocytic (Liberman 1984; FeldKamp 1997), head and neck 
(Kearsley 1991; Rikimaru 1992), ovarian (Alper 2001), cervical (Bianco 2000; Ngan 2001), 
bladder (Chow 2001), and esophageal (Inada 1999; Wang 1999).  EGFR expression is also 
correlated with alterations in cell cycle progression (Giordano 1998), increased tumor  cell 
invasiveness (Damstrup 1998), enhanced angiogenesis (Petit 1997; K erbel 1998a), and decreased 
apoptosis of tumor  cells (Gibson 1999). Overexpression of EGFR in tumor s correlates with 
increased metastasis, decreased survival, and poor prognosis.  EGFR protects malignant tumor  
Nimotuzumab Investigator’s Brochure  Confidential  
Property of InnoCIMAb PTE LTD  Version 20.0  
Page 15 of 249 
(Confidential Information )         cells from the cytotoxic effects of chemotherapy and radiotherapy, making these treatments less 
effective.  
Several strategies have been developed to disrupt EGFR signal transduction. Nimotuzumab is 
one such agent that acts in this way. Nimotuzumab prevents dimerization of the receptor, thereby 
inhibiting tyrosine kinase activity and interfering with cell signal ing pathways involved in cell 
proliferation, metastasis, and repair.  
Other monoclonal antibodies specifically targeting the extracellular domain of EGFR are in 
various stages of development, including cetuximab and panitumumab, which have obtained FDA 
regulatory clearance as oncology treatments. Nimotuzumab has been approve d in ex -USA markets 
but a major market approval is pending.  
Experiments have shown that nimotuzumab requires bivalent binding (attachment with both 
antibody arms to two EGF receptors) for efficient accumulation on cellular surface, in a manner 
analogous to the binding of trastuzumab ( Herceptin®) to the  HER -2 receptor. The ability to form 
bivalent bonds is a function of EGFR density on the cellular surface. Consequently, nimotuzumab 
selectively targets and is active against cells that over -express EGFR, such as tumor  cells, whereas 
activity against normal cells with low EGFR expression is limited.  
This selectivity contrasts with  other EGFR -targeting antibodies, which have significant 
monovalent binding to the receptor (i.e. with a single arm) and inhibit normal EGFR functioning 
even when EGFR expression is low, thereby repressing normal EGFR activity in healthy tissues 
(e.g.: ski n).  
The selective accumulation of nimotuzumab on cancer cells over -expressing the EGFR is a 
mechanistic explanation for the very low incidence of side -effects with this antibody compared to 
EGFR -targeting molecules such as cetuximab (Erbitux®) and panitumumab (Vectibix®).  
Additionally, small molecule tyrosine kinase inhibitors that target the intracellular domain of 
EGFR and inhibit adenosine triphosphate (ATP) binding are also under development, with some 
having already been granted marketing authorization.  
3. PHYSICAL, CHEMICAL, AND PHARMACEUTICAL 
PROPERTIES AND FORMULATION  
3.1 Drug Substance  
 
Nimotuzumab is an IgG subtype 1 kappa monoclonal antibody of approximately 151,000 
daltons.  The light chain is approximately 23,000 daltons and the heavy chain approximately 
52,000 daltons.  
Initially, a murine ascites derived monoclonal antibody m -R3 (also known as ior egf/r3) was 
developed at the Centre for Molecular Immunology (CIM).  This antibody recognizes the human 
EGFR and inhibits binding of EGF to the receptor (Fernández 1989, 1992).   Due to the potential 
detrimental clinical consequences ( e.g., immunogenic response) of using an antibody of murine 
origin, a humanized version of the antibody was constructed.  Nimotuzumab was subsequently 
obtained by amplification and cloning of the DNA  fragments encoding the Complementarity 
Determining Regions (CDR) of the heavy (V H) and light (V k) chain variable regions of m -R3 into 
a human immunoglobulin G (IgG) 1 backbone (Mateo 1997).  Initially this antibody lacked binding 
affinity for EGFR.  However, a reshaped antibody was constructed by identifying and mutating 3 
amino acid residues of muri ne origin (Ser75, Thr76, Thr93) from the non -CDR framework regions 
of the IgG heavy chain into the human framework of the new antibody and full binding affinit y 
for the antigen was restored.  
Nimotuzumab is generated by a well -characterized mouse myeloma host cell system (NS0). 
The antibody is produced by continuous culture in a stirred tank perfusion fermentation process 
Nimotuzumab Investigator’s Brochure  Confidential  
Property of InnoCIMAb PTE LTD  Version 20.0

(Confidential Information )         and purified to yield the drug substance. The manufacturing process for nimotuzumab drug 
substance previously employed hollow fiber (HF) perfusion fermentation technology. This process 
was performed for two years and mainly for research purposes. Early in the  clinical development 
of this product, the process was switched to a 30 L scale stirred tank (ST) perfusion fermentation 
process since it is more amenable to commercial scale up. The switch from HF to ST technology 
occurred in 2001; part of the preclini cal studies described in this Investigator’s Brochure were 
carried out using product derived from the original HF process.  However, an extensive analysis 
of product comparability between the 30 L scale ST and HF process  has shown that the molecules 
have demonstrated equivalence.  In addition, the ST process has been scaled 3 times, from 30 L to 
initial commercial level  of 300 L, from 300 L to 500 L and lately from 500 L to 2000 L and 
subsequent comparability studies have been carried out to demonstrate equ ivalence.   
Since 2004, the non - clinical research has been performed with 300 L fermentation scale.  
Toxicokinetic studies and the 14 -day and 6 -month chronic toxicology studies in monkeys were 
performed using ST materials, 300 L and 500 L materials.   
The 300 L fermentation line was discontinued since 2009, keeping only a 500 L scale in CIM 
Plant II. Later in 2011, 500 L scale was also discontinued and the 2000 L stirred tank fermentation 
process was established as the commercial scale in Antyter facili ty, inside CIM campus.  
In parallel, in the year 2008, a nimotuzumab manufacturing facility based in Beijing, China, 
was accepted as an alternative manufacturing site for drug substance and drug product, with initial 
commercial scale of 1000 L in stirred tank perfusion mode for f ermentation process. Pivotal 
clinical trials and commercial distribution since they have been performed, particularly, but not 
limited to nasopharyngeal, pancreatic and esophageal cancer. Since 2010 another fermentation line 
of 2500 L scale started operati ng, and more recently a third line of 4000 L was added. .

4. NONCLINICAL STUDIES  
 
4.1 Introduction . 
 
InnoCIMAb and partners have conducted supportive nonclinical pharmacology, 
pharmacokinetic, biodistribution and toxicology studies with nimotuzumab.  The results of the in 
vitro  and in vivo pharmacology studies are presented in Section 4.2. Pharmacokinetic and 
biodistribution studies have been performed in mice, rats, rabbits, monkeys and baboons and the 
results are summarized in Section 4.3. Single and repeat -dose toxicity studies have been performed 
in rats and monkeys for up to 6 months.  An overview of the results from the toxicology studies is 
presented in Section 4.4.  
 
4.2 Nonclinical Pharmacology . 
 
The pharmacological activity of nimotuzumab has been evaluated in 7 in vitro  binding and 
immunohistochemistry studies, 4 in vitro  pharmacology studies and 6 in vivo studies.  
To characterize the effects of nimotuzumab , in vitro receptor binding and immunohistochemical 
studies have been conducted in tumor  tissues. An overview of the results of these studies is 
provided in Appendix A, Table A - 1. In vitro  pharmacology studies have been performed to 
characterize the apoptotic and antiproliferative effects of nimotuzumab and to characterize the 
inhibition of EGF dependent EGFR phosphorylation and radiosensitivity effects of nimotuzumab 
in NSCLC cell lines, as  well as to explore a potential ability of the nimotuzumab to induce immune 
antitumor responses probably related to long -term clinical responses observed in patients treated 
with the drug ( Appendix A, Table A - 2). In vivo pharmacology studies in immuno -compromised 
mice to determine the effect of nimotuzumab on tumor s have also been performed ( Appendix A, 
Table A - 3). 
In vitro  studies have demonstrated that nimotuzumab inhibits EGFR activation and requires 
bivalent binding for efficient accumulation on the cell surface.  Studies have shown that 
nimotuzumab has a binding affinity in the order of 10-9 M to EGFR, specifically recognizes 
EGFR/HER -1 but not HER -2, HER -3 or HER -4 and demonstrates positive recognition to fetal and 
adult tissues rich in EGFR and tumor s of epithelial origin.   
Nimotuzumab has been shown to inhibit cell proliferation, induce cell cycle arrest in the G1 
phase of cell  division and induce down regulation of VEGF production. Furthermore, in vitro  
studies have demonstrated that nimotuzumab has immunological activity; specifically, 
nimotuzumab mediates antibody dependent cell mediated cytotoxicity and complement dependent 
cytotoxicity. In vitro  studies have also demonstrated that nimotuzumab inhibits EGF -dependent 
EGFR phosphorylation in NSCLC cell lines, H292 and Ma -1, expressing high or moderate levels 
Nimotuzumab Investigator’s Brochure  Confidential  
Property of InnoCIMAb PTE LTD  Version 20.0  
Page 18 of 249 
(Confidential Information )         of EGFR.  Nimotuzumab also sensitized the H292,  and Ma -1 cell to the cytotoxic effects of 
radiation in vitro . 
Nimotuzumab inhibited tumor  growth and angiogenesis, and induced apoptosis in SCID mice 
implanted with A431 human vulvar epidermoid carcinoma xenografts. When administered in 
combination with radiotherapy, nimotuzumab significantly delayed tumor  growth, inhibited 
angiogenesis, reduced the tumor  proliferation index, increased the number of apoptotic cells and 
reduced the phosphorylation activity of the EGFR in NMRI mice implanted with U87 glioma 
xenografts. In this glioma model, nimotuzumab has shown the ability to target the radio resistant  
CD133+ cancer stem cell population, either administered as a monotherapy or in combination with 
radiation, suggesting a role as radiosensitizer. The capacity of the antibody to target this CD133+ 
population seems to be related to its antiangiogenic activity in this tumor model. The colocalization  
of both molecules, EGFR and CD133, may also contribute to this activity, as has been previously 
demonstrated in in vitro  studies.  
The combination of nimotuzumab and radiation also inhibited tumor  growth in athymic mice 
implanted with H292 and Ma -1 xenografts which express high or moderate levels of EGFR.  This 
study also demonstrated that nimotuzumab increased the radiosensitivity of H292 and Ma -1 in 
vivo. In addition, the combination of CPT -11 plus nimotuzumab showed greater inhibition of 
tumor  growth in athymic mice implanted with gastric GCIY xenografts compared to single agent 
administration. Most recently , in vivo  studies on whic h nimotuzumab was used as monotherapy or 
in combination with paclitaxel or carboplatin on NCI -H292 human lung mucoepidermoid 
carcinoma cell line xenografted into nude mice has shown antitumor effect when nimotuzumab 
was used as monotherapy and this antitum or effect was significantly increased with the 
combination with paclitaxel or carboplatin.  
Altogether, these  data suggest that nimotuzumab has a mechanism of action similar to that of 
other  existing monoclonal antibodies directed against the EGFR such as cetuximab, panitumumab 
and matuzumab.  
 
4.3 Nonclinical Pharmacokinetics and Biodistribution.  
 
Single -dose pharmacokinetic studies were performed in mice, rats, rabbits, monkeys and 
baboons using 99mTc, 125I, 188Re or ELISA assay to determine the pharmacokinetic parameters for 
nimotuzumab [e.g., half -life, area -under -the-curve (AUC), volume of distribution, clearances, 
etc.].  Biodistribution studies in xenograft mice injected with human cell lines (H -125 lung 
adenocarcinoma, U -87 human glioblastoma multiforme, A431 human vulvar epidermoid 
carcinoma, MDA -MB-468 human breast carcinoma cell lines) were  performed to evaluate the 
ability of nimotuzumab to bind to human tumor s in vivo .  Single dose  biodistribution studies were 
also carried out using 99mTc, 188Re or 64Cu in normal mice, rats, and baboons. A summary of the 
pharmacokinetic and biodistribution study results is provided in Appendix A, Table A - 4. 
The pharmacokinetic profile of nimotuzumab was evaluated in nine (9) studies conducted in 
mice, rats, rabbits, monkeys, and baboons.  
In Balb /c mice, the blood radioactivity -time curve was best -fit to a monoexponentially  equation 
with a half -life (T ½) of 14.27 h.  
In Crl:BALB /c-nu mice, using intravenous (i.v .) and intraperitoneal (i.p .) administration, for 
the i.v . administration values of AUC 0-last increased with increase of the dose ( Appendix A, Table 
A-4) and for the i.p . administration values of AUC 0-last also increased with increase of the dose with 
a serum concentration of DE -766 Cmax being reached between 8 and 24 h after administration 
and the values increased in proportion to the increase of the dose ( Appendix A, Table A -4).

(Confidential Information )         In Wistar rats, serum disappearance curves were best fit by a two -compartment model having 
a mean distribution half -life (T 1/2) of 0.25 hours and a mean elimination half -life (T 1/2) of 13.89 
hours and  mean systemic clearance of 5.7 mL/h/kg.  
In Crl:CD(SD) rats, serum disappearance curves were best fit by a non -compartment model 
having a mean half -life (T 1/2) of (135 ± 12) h, (157 ± 24) h and (140 ± 9) h and a mean systemic 
clearance CL of (0.518 ± 0.044) mL/h/kg, (0.535 ± 0.016) mL/h/kg and (0.581 ± 0.040) mL/h/kg 
for the doses of 1.14 mg/kg, 5.7 mg/kg and 26.0 mg/kg respectively.  
In rabbits, as the dose level increased, clearance decreased and half -life increased, so that total 
serum exposure to nimotuzumab (AUC) increased more than proportionally with dose level.  
In green monkeys, nimotuzumab exhibited a mean elimination half -life ranging from 7 to 8 
days, and mean clearance of 13 mL/day/kg.  
In a single dose toxicology study in cynomolgus monkeys, nimotuzumab exhibited a mean 
elimination half-life ranging from 39.81 h (for a dose level of 5.71 mg/kg representing 1x the 
human therapeutic dose of 400mg) to 88.75 h (for a dose level of 50.00 mg/kg represented 8.75 
times the human therapeutic dose of 400 mg). The mean systemic clearance was 0.50 mL/h/k g and 
0.22 mL/h/kg respectively for the 2 dose levels.  
Pharmacokinetic parameters in cynomolgus monkeys were also assessed in a repeated dose 
toxicology study where monkeys received 5.71, 28.55 or 50.00 mg/kg of nimotuzumab via a 1 -
hour infusion once a week for 26 weeks.  
 
• The mean maximum concentration ranged between 124.50 g/mL and 2718.27 g/mL 
in the dose range of 5.71 to 50.00 mg/kg/week administered for 26 weeks.  Dose -
normalized C max ranged between 21.80 kg· g/mL/mg to 55.75 kg· g/mL/mg.  
• The mean area under the curve from time zero to the last measurable concentration 
(AUC 0-t) ranged between 5886.69 g·h/mL and 196332.77 g·h/mL in the dose range 
of 5.71 to 50.00 mg/kg/week administered 26 weeks.  The dose -normalized AUC 0-t, 
ranged from 1030.94 kg· g·h/mL/mg to 3926.66 kg· g·h/mL/mg.  
• The dose -normalized C max and AUCs indicate a more than proportional increase in 
exposure with increase in dose from 5.71 to 50.00 mg/kg/week.  The data suggest that 
this more than proportional increase is independent of gender or dosing week.  
• The mean terminal elimination half -life ranged from 40.24 h to 184.26 h and increased 
as dose increased.  
 
In baboons, radiolabeled nimotuzumab was cleared from the circulation with biexponential 
kinetics having a mean distribution half -life (T 1/2) of 3.63 h and a mean elimination half -life 
(T1/2) of 42.19 h. The half -lives obtained in this study are also consistent with previous clearance 
studies with other humanized monoclonal antibodies in other animal models conducted over a 
comparable time scale which measured half -lives between 0.1 and 104 h  (Haunschild 1995, 
Baselga 1994, Khetarpal 1995, Murthy 1987, Ta kahashi 1993, Dadparvar 1994, Steiner 1995).  
Six non-clinical  studies examining the biodistribution of nimotuzumab have been conducted in 
mice, rats, and baboons.  
In athymic nude mice bearing tumor  xenografts, the biodistribution data shows a higher uptake 
of radioactivity into the tumor . Tumor  uptake data suggested that there is a threshold number of 
EGFR per cell above which nimotuzumab (with a binding affinity in the order of 10-8 M) will bind 
tumor  cells in vivo  and will accumulate in the xenografted tumor s (as seen in the H -125, A431 and 
MDA -MB-468 cell lines), and below which the antibody will not bind or accumulate in the 
xenografted tumor s (as seen with the U -87 cell line). Significant accumulation of the radioactivity 
was found in the kidneys suggesting compound clearance via the urinary route. The low 
accumulation of radioactivity in the liver and small intestine of athymic nude mice suggests that

(Confidential Information )         the main route of elimination for this radiopharmaceutical is not via the hepatobiliary -intestine 
route.  
An additional study in athymic nude mice bearing A431 tumor  xenografts showed a significant 
increase in antibody concentration from 4 to 24 h post -injection of 64Cu-labeled nimotuzumab. 
Other organs with notable distribution of the antibody included liver and kidney.  
In BALB /c mice, significant accumulation occurred in the blood, liver, kidney, small intestines 
and large intestines at one-hour post-administration and remained visible at 72 h post -injection.  
In Wistar rats, localization of the radioactivity was significant in the kidney.  Accumulation of 
radiolabeled nimotuzumab was also observed in the liver, intestines, lung and spleen.   
In baboons, after administration of 188Re-labeled nimotuzumab, the liver, heart, kidneys, urinary 
bladder and gastrointestinal tract were visible immediately and remained visible through 48 h post -
injection. The results indicated that the liver was the major organ of excretion for radiolabeled 
nimotuzumab in the baboon.  
 
4.4 Nonclinical Toxicology . 
 
The safety of nimotuzumab has been evaluated in two single -dose intravenous studies in rats 
(Studies #96/31 and #AcMU0499), a single dose intravenous study in cynomolgus monkeys 
(Study # ITR 30143), three 14 -day repeat -dose intravenous toxicity studies in rats (Studies 
#CIMYM -003-TS , #AcMU0599 and #209517), a 4-week repeat -dose intravenous toxicity study 
in rats ( Study# B100433), two 14 -day repeat -dose intravenous toxicity studies in green monkeys 
(Studies #R3AD0997 and #AR3R0101), two 26 -week repeat -dose intravenous toxicity studies in 
monkeys (Study #PR3M0403 - green monkeys and Study # ITR 30103 – cynomolgus monkeys), 
a local tolerance study in rabbits (#97/26) and an in vitro  cardiotoxicity study in Human Embryonic 
Kidney (HEK) cells (Study # IPST 800408 -1). Results are provided in Appendix A, Table A - 5, 
Table A - 6, Table A - 7 and Table A -8. 
Nimotuzumab was well tolerated in both rats and monkeys, producing minimal adverse effects 
when given to either species daily for up to 2 weeks or to monkeys weekly for 26 weeks.  This 
safety profile compares favorably to that of approved monoclonal antibo dy products, including 
cetuximab and panitumumab, which also target EGFR.  
 
5 EFFECTS IN HUMANS . 
 
Nimotuzumab is an intravenously administered human monoclonal antibody directed against 
EGFR. EGFR is known to be overexpressed on many human tumor s and has been demonstrated 
to be a key driver of uncontrolled proliferation of tumor  cells in vitro  and in vivo . 
As of October 2025 , 51 clinical trials have been completed with nimotuzumab in several 
cancer indications as summarized in Table 2 . Data is presented on 5653  patients in 51 of these 
completed trials ( 3823  patients recruiting to nimotuzumab arm and 1830  patients  to the control 
arm). Efficacy results are provided by study ( Sections 5.1, through 5. 52) and an overall summary 
of safety is provided in Section 5.55. A listing of ong oing studies is provided in Table 3.  
In the completed trials, nimotuzumab was given either as a single agent or in combination 
with chemotherapy and/or radiotherapy. The primary objectives of these studies were to establish 
the safety, efficacy, pharmacokinetic, pharmacodynamic and immunogeni c profiles of 
nimotuzumab.  Adult patients were treated with a range of doses from 50 mg to 1200 mg, either 
as a single dose or as multiple sequential doses, while pediatric patients were dosed according to 
body surface area (150 mg/m2). 
Serum pharmacokinetic and biodistribution data for nimotuzumab in patients with cancer have 
been obtained across multiple clinical studies ( Section 5. 53). Interpretation of the available data

(Confidential Information )         5.1 Study No. IIC RD EC -070 (completed, Breast) . 
 
This was a Phase I, open -label, dose escalation clinical trial to assess the safety of 
nimotuzumab in patients with advanced breast cancer. Patients were divided into 4 cohorts, and 
each received 10 weekly intravenous infusions of 50, 100, 200, or 400 mg o f nimotuzumab over 
a period of 30 minutes. Concurrently, patients were administered four 21 -day cycles of 
doxorubicin (60 mg/m2) and cyclophosphamide (600 mg/m2). This study was conducted in one 
investigation site in Cuba and was initiated in October 2005 and completed in November 2006.  
Thirteen patients, all female [mean age 47 years (range 30 to 63)] were enrolled in the study 
and treated with nimotuzumab. Following administration of the 10 weekly doses of nimotuzumab 
in combination with chemotherapy, 101 adverse events were reported in  the 13 patients enrolled 
in this study. Of the 95 AEs for which causality was reported, 60 were considered at least possibly 
related to study treatment. The most frequently reported AEs related to study treatment included 
facial erythema (8 subjects; 62%) , mucositis (3 subjects; 23%), nausea (2 subjects; 15%), 
headache (2 subjects; 15%) and pain at injection site (2 subjects; 15%). A summary of related 
adverse events is provided in Appendix B , Table B -1. The events were primarily mild to 
moderate in severity and were all considered reversible. In the study, there were 2 SAEs in 2 
patients. None of the serious adverse events were considered by the investigators to be related to 
nimotuzumab treatment.  
 
5.2 Study No. YMB -1000 -015 (completed, Colorectal) . 
 
A two -cohort, open -label, multi -center Phase II trial was performed to evaluate the safety and 
efficacy of nimotuzumab in patients with irinotecan -refractory metastatic colorectal cancer in 
two dosing regimens: 400 mg weekly and 400 mg every 2 weeks.  The primary objective was the 
assessment of objective response rate of nimotuzumab in combination with irinotecan. Secondary 
objectives included progression -free survival  (PFS) , time to tumor  progression  (TTP) , overall 
survival (OS), and pharmacokinetics. Pati ents were treated with 400 mg nimotuzumab on a 
weekly basis for 12 weeks, followed by 400 mg nimotuzumab every 2 weeks. Concurrently, 
patients receive  irinotecan at the same dose and schedule as the patient’s last irinotecan regimen. 
Due to the lower than anticipated response rate, this study was terminated after the completion 
of the first cohort (400 mg weekly in combination with irinotecan) and did n ot enroll any patients 
into the second cohort (400 mg every 2 weeks in combination with irinotecan). This trial was  
conducted in Canada in 15 investigation sites and was  initiated in July 2007 and completed in 
August 2008.   
A total of 61 patients (29 males/32 females) with a mean age of 60.1 years (range 23 to 83) 
were recruited for treatment.  All patients were eligible for efficacy and safety analysis.  
All 61 subjects (100%) experienced at least one AE during  the study.  The most reported  AEs 
were fatigue (37 subjects; 61 %), nausea (32 subjects; 52 %), diarrhea (28 subjects; 46 %), 
alopecia (26 subjects; 43 %), anorexia (25 subjects; 41 %) and constipation (25 subjects; 41 %). 
Forty -four (44; 72 %) patients had at least one AE considered to be related to study drug.  The 
most common AEs (≥15 % of patients) related to study drug were  fatigue (21 subjects; 34 %), 
dermatitis (acneiform), (12 subjects; 21 %) , diarrhea, (11 subjects; 18 %), nausea (10 subjects; 
16 %), and exfoliative rash (9 subjects; 15 %).  A listing of related AEs by grade is shown in 
Appendix B , Table  B-2. Nine patients were withdrawn from the study early due to AEs. None 
of the AEs leading to withdrawal were  related to study drug.   
In the study, there were 30 serious adverse events in 20 subjects. Out of 30 SAEs, there were 
2 SAEs in 2 patients (3.28%) that were  related to the study drug. Possibly related SAEs included

There were 4 SAEs that lead to subject death: dyspnea (Subject 03 -010), metastatic neoplasm 
(Subject 08 -001), acute respiratory distress syndrome (Subject 13 -004), and disease progression 
(Subject 15 -007). These 4 SAEs which resulted in death were consider ed unrelated to study drug.  
The combination of irinotecan and nimotuzumab was assessed in this population to determine 
if the overall response rate would provide a clinical benefit. In the intent -to-treat (ITT) 
population, an objective response rate of 1.6 % was observed (1 PR) and c linical benefit rate was 
shown to be 26 % (1 PR and 15 SD). Progression -free survival and time to tumor  progression 
were identical, with a range of 0.8 to 9.5 months and a median of 2.3 months. Overall survival 
ranged from 1.6 to 14.2 months and had a medi an value of 6.1 months.  
This study confirms the improved safety and tolerability of nimotuzumab, with no subjects 
experiencing severe rash reactions and no subjects requiring dose reductions, dose interruptions 
or withdrawals due to nimotuzumab  treatment.  Irinotecan was administered concurrently and 
was provided in 3 different dosing schedules and dose levels to match administration schedules 
already provided to each subject. This regimen was also well tolerated with a safety profile that 
was c onsistent with known events.  Althou gh the overall response rate was lower than expected 
in this study, there remained 11 % of subjects with stable disease at study termination.  
 
5.3 Study No. IIC RD EC -134 (completed, Colorectal) . 
 
This was an open -label, non -randomized, non -controlled, dose finding, pharmacokinetic, 
single -center, phase I trial to evaluate the safety of single -agent nimotuzumab in patients with 
locally advanced and/or metastatic CRC who have clinical failure after r eceiving at least one 
oxaliplatin CT -regimen. Every patient was administered weekly 200, 400, 800, or 1200 mg 
nimotuzumab infusion for seven weeks and then maintenance dose of every 2 weeks, until 2 
years or significant toxicity. Primary endpoint was to ev aluate the safety of nimotuzumab up to 
1200 mg in a long-lasting  schedule. Secondary endpoints included the pharmacokinetic profile 
of nimotuzumab for each dose level and the preliminary efficacy of the monotherapy assessing 
a comparison with historical  control . 
This study was initiated in May 2011 and completed in July 2015. Twenty -two patients were 
included in the study. Two patients  assigned one each to the 200 and 1200 mg nimotuzumab who 
early abandoned the study, were judged to have not achieved endpoints  and were then replaced. 
Twenty patients were included in the analysis of clinical activity, having received the scheduled 
induction treatment (at least 7 doses).  
Safety analysis was based on 21 subjects who received at least one dose of nimotuzumab. No 
treatment -related serious or severe adverse events were reported for doses up to 1200 mg. All 
subjects experienced at least one adverse event during the study, but t here was no evidence of a 
relationship between the dose and the intensity, duration or frequency of these adverse events. 
Of all the 108 AEs reported, 9 events (8.3%) in 4 patients (19%) were  related to the study drug. 
The most common one was rash (3.7% of  reported AEs), observed in 2 patients (9.5%) at 200 
and 800 mg levels. In general, most AE were mild to moderate (96.3%), except for 4 no 
treatment -related severe adverse events (3.7%) in 3 patients at 200 and 800 mg levels.  
Out of 20 evaluable patients, one (400 mg level) displayed the best  response of partial 
response (PR), while 5 (one in 200mg, 2 in 400mg and one in 1200mg) exhibited stable disease 
(SD) and 14 progressed (PD). The median overall survival of patients administered 200, 400, 
800, or 1200 mg nimotuzumab were 28.17, 55.50, 22. 17 or 29.97 months, respectively, 
comparing favorably with those of historical controls in this setting. Although the study was too

5.4 Study No. DE766 -A-J102 (completed, esophageal) . 
 
This was a Phase 1, open label , escalating dose, multicenter study in patients with locally 
advanced esophageal cancer conducted in Japan and sponsored by Daiichi Sankyo Co. Ltd. The 
objective of this study was to evaluate the safety of DE -766 in combination with cisplatin, 
fluorouraci l and radiation therapy in patients with stage II, III (excluding T4), or IV (M1 lymph 
node involvement, excluding  T4) esophageal cancer. This study was conducted in 7 investigation 
sites in Japan and was initiated in December  2010 and completed in April 2015.  
Nimotuzumab was administered  at 200 mg (Level 1) or 400 mg (Level 2) once weekly as an 
i.v. infusion from d1 of Course 1 to the end of Course 2. Each course consisted of 4 weeks. 
Cisplatin was administered at a dose of 75 mg/m2 as an i.v . infusion on d1 of each course, 
followed by 4 -weeks rest period. 5 -FU was administered  at a dose of 1000 mg/m2 as a continuous 
i.v. infusion for 4 consecutive days from d1 of each course. Radiotherapy was given at a dose of 
1.8 Gy once daily for 5 days a week for 6 weeks fo r a total of 50.4 Gy in 30 fractions.  
The primary endpoint of the study was to determine dose -limiting toxicity (DLT) and 
maximum -tolerated dose (MTD) of DE -766 in combination with chemoradiotherapy . The 
secondary endpoints  were PK, antitumor effect (complete response rate, PFS and OS rates at 1 -
year, 2 -year and 3 -year), safety, immunogenicity (HAHA response) and exploratory efficacy -
related biomarkers (EGFR expression, KRAS, expression of proteins or genes in tumors, 
expres sion of proteins in serum and analysis of FcγR polymorphisms in blood -derived DNA).  
A total of 10 patients (7 males and 3 females) with mean age 62.0 years (range 51 to 71 years) 
were included on the study. All 10 patients included in the study received at least one dose of the 
study drug and were included in the safety analysis set. DLTs were evaluated during the 
chemoradiation period and were analyzed in 9 subjects included in the MTD analysis set. One 
subject withdrew from the study  treatment after receiving only the first dose of DE -766 only, 
without receiving chemoradiotherapy, which precluded appropriate evaluation of safety , and this 
subject was accordingly excluded from the MTD analysis set.  
The DLT, the primary endpoint, was analyzed in 9 subjects included in the MTD analysis set, 
and the MTD was estimated based on the results of DLT evaluation. At the dosage Level 1 (200 
mg) there were 7 patients  (77.7 %) with non -DLT and 2 subjects (22.2 %) with DLT. In the MTD 
analysis set, a total of 2 patients  who experienced  one patient infection and the other renal 
disorder under treatment of 200 mg (Level 1) were considered to have DLTs. The frequency of 
DLTs was 22.2 % (2/9 patients). The frequency of  DLTs at 200 mg (Level 1) satisfied the criteria 
for dose increase specified in the protocol and the MTD was estimated to be at least 200 mg; 
however, the dose of nimotuzumab was not increased to 400 mg (Level 2).  
All patients experienced at least one treatment -emergent adverse event. A total of 341 
treatment -emergent adverse events (AEs) were reported in 10 patients. Of the 341 AEs, 123 AEs 
were not related and 218 AEs (63.9 %) in 10 patients (100 %) were reported to be related to the 
study drug. The most common study -drug related AEs (> 3 patients, 30.0 %) were lymphocyte 
count decreased (8 subjects, 80.0 %), neutrophil count decreased (8 subjects, 80.0 %), white 
blood cell count decreased (8 subjects, 80.0 %), pla telet count decreased (7 subjects, 70.0 %), 
anemia (7 subjects, 70.0 %), hypoalbuminemia  (6 subjects, 60.0 %), hyponatremia  (5 subjects, 
50.0 %), weight loss (5 subjects, 50.0 %), radiation esophagitis  (5 subjects, 50.0 %), protein total 
decreased (4 subjects, 40.0 %), decreased appetite (4 subjects, 40.0 %), fatigue (4 subjects, 40.0 
%), nausea (4 subjects, 40.0 %), and radiation pneumonitis (3 subject, 30.0 %). A listing of 
treatment -related adverse e vents is provided in Appendix B, Table B -4.

5.5 Study No. II RD EC -075 (completed, Esophageal Cancer) . 
 
This was a phase II, open label , controlled, randomized and multicenter clinical trial to 
evaluate the anti -tumo r effect of monoclonal antibody nimotuzumab combined with radiation 
therapy and chemotherapy for the treatment of malignant, non -resectable, esophageal tumor s.  
Patients were recruited into 2 cohorts: group I was treated for six weeks with 200 mg 
nimotuzumab, for five weeks with radiation therapy and for 14 weeks with chemotherapy (5 -FU 
750 mg/m2 and cisplatin 75 mg/m2).  Group II was treated with  radiotherapy for five weeks and 
with chemotherapy for 14 weeks (cisplatin 75 mg/m2 and 5 -FU 750 mg/m2). The primary 
objective was to assess objective response rate. Secondary objectives included evaluation of 
safety, quality of life and immunogenicity. The study was conducted in 6 investigation sites and 
was initiated in December 2005 and was completed in January 2010.  
A total of 63 patients were enrolled in the study.  Thirty -three (33) patients (26 males and 7 
females) with a mean age of 58.53 years were randomized to the nimotuzumab group and 30 
patients (25 males and 5 females) with a mean age of 58.9 years were rand omized to the control 
group.  
The most common adverse events related to nimotuzumab were headache, phlebitis and pain 
when swallowing (2 events each).  See Appendix B, Table B -5 for a listing of the related adverse 
events with severities. There were no serious adverse events reported in the study and no deaths 
were related to nimotuzumab.  
The results for the objective response were 47.8 % and 15.4 %, for the nimotuzumab and 
control groups, respectively (p=0.014).  Regarding clinical benefit, the values were 60.9 % versus 
26.9 % in favor  of the group treated with nimotuzumab plus radiation -chemotherapy (p=0.017).  
There were no significant differences between the groups with respect to survival; the median 
was 8.1 months for the nimotuzumab group vs. 2.97 months for the radiation -chemothe rapy 
group.

This was a phase II, double -blind, placebo -controlled, randomized and multicenter clinical 
trial conducted in China and sponsored by Biotech Pharmaceuticals Ltd to evaluate the anti -
tumoral effect, safety and toxicity of monoclonal antibody nimotuzumab com bined with 
radiation therapy and chemotherapy for the treatment of patients with locally advanced 
esophageal squamous cell carcinoma. Primary objectives of the study were the evaluation of 
complete remission rate 14 weeks after the end of the treatment and  secondary objectives

Patients were recruited into 2 cohorts: Experimental Arm: patients received chemotherapy

every four (4) weeks for 4 cycles and radiotherapy 61.2 Gy of three dimensional conformal 
radiotherapy (3DCRT) or intensity modulated radiation therapy (IMRT) in 34 fractions of 1.8 
Gy/day for 5 days a week for 6.8 weeks plus nimot uzumab 200 mg intravenously once a week 
for 9 weeks and Control Arm: patients received the same chem otherapy and radiotherapy 
regimen as the Experimental Arm plus placebo 200 mg intravenously once a week for 9 weeks. 
The study was initiated in April 2010 and was completed in July 2013.  
A total of 160 patients were randomly assigned to either of the arms. Eighty  (80) patients (62 
males and 18 females) with a mean age of 60.08 years were randomized to the Experimental Arm 
and 80 patients (65 males and 15 females) with a mean age of 60.43 years were randomized to 
the Control Arm. Of the 160 patients included in the study, 159 patients received at least one 
dose of nimotuzumab or placebo. From them,  80 patients were evaluable on the nimotuzumab 
arm and 79 patients on the placebo -controlled ar m. 
A total of 118 (73.8 %) out of 160 patients experienced at least one adverse event (AE). Sixty 
(60) patients (75 %) on the nimotuzumab arm and 58 patients (72.5 %) on the control arm. From 
these 118 patients, a total of 764 AEs was reported, 389 on the nim otuzumab arm and 375 on the 
control arm. The most frequently reported AEs on the nimotuzumab arm, regardless of 
relationship to the study drug, were nausea (27 subjects, 33.8 %), lymphopenia (21 subjects, 26.3 
%), neutropenia (21 subjects, 26.3 %), cough ( 20 subjects, 25.0 %), esophagitis radiation (19 
subjects, 23.8 %), vomiting (19 subjects, 23.8 %), dysphagia (18 subjects, 22.5 %), and anorexia 
(16 subjects, 20.0 %). Eleven (11) patients (13.8 %) out of 80 reported 13 study drug -related 
AEs. The most com mon study -drug related AEs (> 2 patients, 2.5%) were nausea (3 subjects, 
3.75 %) and fatigue (2 subjects, 2.5 %). A listing of treatment -related adverse events is provided 
in Appendix B, Table B -7. 
Two (2) (1.25 %) patients experienced serious adverse events (SAEs) during the study period, 
all of which were single events reported. One (1) patient from the nimotuzumab arm had an SAE 
consisting in dysphagia and 1 patient from the control arm had an SAE  consisting in vomiting, 
resulting in death. The single SAE consisting of dysphagia reported on the nimotuzumab arm 
was considered by the investigators to be related to radiotherapy treatment and not to be related 
to nimotuzumab treatment.  
Statistically significant differences were observed between nimotuzumab and placebo groups 
in terms of the primary endpoint the completed response rate (CRR), being 26.3 % for the 
nimotuzumab arm vs 11.4 % for the placebo arm with a p = 0.017. Median overa ll survival (OS) 
was 22.1 months for the treatment arm compared to 19.6 months for the placebo arm which was 
not statistically significant and the survival rate at 2 years was 49 % for the treatment arm vs 39.2 
% for the placebo arm respectively  
 
5.8 Study No. IIC RD EC -0163 (completed, Esophageal Cancer).  
 
This was a Phase IV , uncontrolled, open and multicenter clinical trial to evaluate the adverse 
events, OS and PFS, clinical response and quality of life (QoL), in patients with inoperable 
tumors of esophagus  of epithelial origin. The study was conducted in 14 investigation sites in 
Cuba and was initiated in July 2016 and concluded in July 2019.  
In this study patients received nimotuzumab 200 mg i.v . infusion once a week for 6 weeks 
and subsequently every 2 weeks until non -tolerable toxicity or withdrawal from study . If the 
patient was medically fit for radiotherapy concurrently received 50.4 Gy in no more than 30

the study , 100 were evaluable for safety and response, 92 newly diagnosed patients and 8

is presented in Appendix C, Table C -1.

received nimotuzumab plus chemotherapy  reached a median OS of 6.8 months (95% CI, 3.8 -
9.8), the 12 -months OS rates of 18.8%, and 12 -month  PFS rates of 7.5%. Patients  treated with

constipation (p=0.04), eating difficulties (p=0.0006) and chokin g when swallowing (p=0.0001), 
but increase in dysphagia (p=0.02).

combined radiotherapy and chemotherapy treatment . Nim otuzumab injection  was administered 
once a week for 6 weeks  at three different dosages: 100 mg, 200 mg and 400 mg. Chemotherapy 
regimen consisted of cisplatin + 5 -Fu. Cisplatin (DDP) 25 mg/m2 /day, intravenous infusion on 
days 1 – 3; 5-Fu 600 mg/m2 /day, continuous intravenous infusion on days 1 – 3, for a total course 
of chemotherapy at 1, 5, 9 and 13 weeks; rad iation therapy regimen consisted of 1.8 Gy/day, on 
days 1 – 5, every week, 34 times in total, total dose of 61.2 Gy.  
At the end of the study, a total of 11 patients were enrolled, and all recruited patients 
completed nimotuzumab treatment. One patient from the 200 mg dose group withdrew the study 
due to withdrawal of the informed consent and one patient from the 400 mg d ose group was lost 
to follow -up.  
Except for the patient who voluntarily requested to withdraw from the trial in the 5th week of 
medication, the remaining 10 patients completed nimotuzumab 6 as per the protocol . Therefore, 
no patients discontinued treatment due to treatment -related adverse events, and no patients 
experienced protocol violations.  Due to the patient withdrawal and loss of follow -up, 10 cases 
were evaluable at 7 weeks, with a response rate of 60.0%, and a disease control rate of 100%; 8 
cases were evaluable at 11 weeks, with a n ORR of 75.0% and a DCR of 100%.  
Safety data collected in this study include serious adverse events, early withdrawal , reported 
adverse events and investigator's manual inconsistent description of nimotuzumab -related 
adverse events and nimotuzumab -related rash . 
Treatment -related a dverse events occurred in all patients. Among the adverse events, 
leukopenia (11 cases), neutrophil decrease (6 cases), vomiting (5 cases), and fever (5 cases) were 
the most common. Most adverse events were graded 1 – 2, according to CTCAE3.0. Only 2 cases  
of leukocyte decrease were classified as grade 3. One of the cases with leukocyte decrease 
occurred at week 9, when the patient had finished nimotuzumab treatment. After 3 weeks of 
treatment, it was considered that the event was caused by chemotherapy.  A listing of treatment -
related adverse events is provided in Appendix B, Table B -9. 
According to the investigator s, the common adverse events that are or may be related to 
nimotuzumab include leukopenia (7  cases), vomiting (5 cases), fever (5 cases). Most of them 
were classified as grade 1 – 2. Only one grade 3 leukopenia adverse event was classified as 
related or possibly related to nimotuzumab.  None of grade 3 adverse events were DLT.  
No serious adverse events were observed, and no participants withdrew from the study due to 
adverse events. During the study period  no death occurred. No DLT occurred during the study. 
All the three doses evaluated were well tolerated, therefore, no maximum tolerated dose was 
found in this study.  
In conclusion, nimotuzumab combined with radiotherapy and chemotherapy failed to reach 
the maximum tolerated dose in the treatment of locally advanced esophageal cancer. Low (100 
mg), medium (200 mg) and high doses (400 mg) were well tolerated. No serious adverse events 
or unexpected adverse events occurred.

5.12 Study No. OSAG -101-BSC -05 (completed, DIPG).  
 
This was a Phase III, open label, multicenter, single arm study designed to assess the 
effectiveness of nimotuzumab in combination with standard local radiotherapy in newly 
diagnosed intrinsic pontine gliomas of children and adolescents.  Patients were tre ated with 
weekly nimotuzumab infusions (150 mg/m2) for 11 weeks in combination with 6 weeks of 
radiotherapy. The primary objective of this study was to assess progression free survival. 
Secondary objectives included objective response rate (CR+PR+SD), dura tion of response and 
overall survival. This study was conducted in 9 clinical sites in Germany. The study was initiated 
in April 2006 and completed in July 2009.  
Forty -two patients (16 males/26 females) with a mean age of 7.55 years (range 3 to 15 years) 
were enrolled in the study. All patients were assessed for safety and efficacy.  
All patients experienced at least one treatment -emergent adverse event. A total of 368 
treatment -emergent adverse events were reported. Out of 368 AEs, 64 AEs reported in 21 patients 
(50%) were assessed as at least possibly or probably related to study dru g. The most reported  
study drug -related AEs (> 2 subjects, 4.76%) were alopecia (6 subjects, 14.3%), vomiting (3 
subjects, 7.1%), headache (3 subjects, 7.1%), and radiation skin injury (2 subjects, 7.1%). See 
Appendix B, Table B -12 for a complete listing o f related AEs.  
There was a total of 66 serious  adverse events (SAEs) reported in 35 patients (83.3%). Of the 
66 SAEs reported, there were 8 SAEs reported in 2 patients (4.76%) that were considered to be 
related to the study and in one (1) patient the SAE was not assessable. A listing of related SAEs 
is presented in Appendix C, Table C -1.  
There were 33 patients who died during  the study. In all cases, the investigators assessed the 
cause of death to be unrelated to study drug and due to progressive disease.  
Median progression free survival was 175 days [95% CI: 145 - 184], while median overall 
survival was 285 days [95% CI: 239 - 352].
