endpoint of the study was to determine the therapeutic efficacy of the combination treatment of 
radiotherapy and nimotuzumab in children and adolescents  with DIPG and secondary endpoints 
were to determine the PFS rate at 6 months, Overall survival, objective response, duration of 
response and toxicity. This study was conducted in 5 investigation sites in Cuba and 3 sites in 
Brazil. The study initiated in November 2007 and completed in June 2014.  
Forty -five patients (19 males (42.2 %)/26 females (57.8 %)) with a mean age of 7.87 years 
(range 2 to 17 years) were enrolled in the study. All patients were evaluable for safety and 37 for 
efficacy analysis.  
A total of 569 treatment -emergent adverse events (AEs) were reported in 35 patients (77.8 
%). Of the 569 AEs, 515 AEs were not related and 54 AEs in 14 patients (31.1 %) were reported 
to be related to the study drug. The most common study -drug related AEs (> 3 patients, 6.7 %) 
were vomiting (8 subjects, 17.8 %), headache (4 subjects, 8.9 %), constipation (4 subjects, 8.9 
%) and bronchospasm (3 subjects, 6.7 %). A listing of treatment -related adverse events is 
provided in Appendix B, Table B -13. 
There was a total of 36 serious adverse events (SAEs) reported in 18 patients (40.0 %). Of the 
36 SAEs reported, there were 4 SAEs reported in 2 patients (4.4 %) that were considered to be 
related to the study drug. Related SAEs were hiccups, pale skin and  sweating reported in 1 patient 
and anaphylactic shock reported in another patient. A listing of related SAEs is presented in 
Appendix C, Table C -1. There were 21 patients who died during the course of the study. In 
none of the cases, the investigators ass essed the cause of death to be unrelated to study drug,  and 
it was due to disease progression.  
The overall response rate was 44.4 %, the disease control rate was 75.5 %, the median 
progression free survival time was 9.03 months,  and the median overall survival time was 15.1 
months. The 2 -year PFS and OS rates were 18.0 % and 40.5 % respectively.  
 
 
5.14 Study No. BN -001 PED -04 (completed, Pediatric Glioma) . 
 
This was a Phase II, open -label, multicenter study designed to evaluate the efficacy of 
nimotuzumab in chemotherapy -resistant high -grade gliomas in children and adolescents. The 
study included pediatric patients (≥3 to ≤20 years) with a histologically proven diagnosis of high 
grade gliomas of WHO Grade III or IV, radiologically proven progressive disease following 
primary or relapse treatment, at least one -dimensionally measurable disease, suffi cient 
hematological , renal and hepatic function, a life expecta ncy of ≥ 4 weeks upon entry into the 
study, and without chemo - or radiotherapy within the last 3 weeks prior entry.  Patients were 
administered  nimotuzumab 150 mg/m2 i.v. infusion once a week for 6 weeks, they had an 
evaluation on week 8 and if there was a stable disease or better response,  they continued  
maintenance treatment of nimotuzumab at 150 mg/m2 every 3 weeks until disease progression, 
death or unmanageable toxicity. The study was conducted in 27 centers in Germany and it 
initiated in June 2004 and completed in April 2007.  
Forty -seven (47) patients were enrolled and treated with at least one dose of nimotuzumab.  
Safety data are available for all 47 patients.  Twenty -nine (29) boys and 18 girls, with a mean 
age of 10 years (range 4 to 17) were assessed for safety and forty -five (45) patients (27 males

phase) then once every 2 weeks for 10 weeks (consolidation phase).  The primary objectives of 
the study were to evaluate the objective response rate and the safety profile of nimotuzumab in 
this popul ation. The study was conduc ted in 12 investigation sites in Canada and United States 
and it initiated in February 2008 and completed in June 2010.  
Forty -six (46) patients were enrolled in the study. Forty -four (44) were treated with at least 
one dose of nimotuzumab and were therefore assessable for safety and efficacy.   Twenty (20) 
males and 24 females participated in the study.  The mean age of the patients was 7.5 years (range 
3 to 17 years).  
There were 488 AEs reported in 43 patients (97.7 %) during the study period. Of 488 AEs 
reported, there were 54 AEs reported in 24 patients (54.5 %) that were considered to be drug -
related AEs. The most common study -drug related AEs (> 2 subjects, 4.55%) w ere nausea (4 
subjects, 9.1 %), rash (4 subjects, 9.1 %) and lymphopenia (3 subjects, 6.8 %). A list of related 
AEs is provided in Appendix B, Table B -15.  
A total of 19 patients (43.18%) experienced 30 SAEs. Out of 30 SAE reported, 2 SAEs in 1 
patient (22.7%) were considered to be related to the study drug. Two patients discontinued study 
drug due to their SAEs; one patient discontinued due to hydrocephalus while the other 
discontinued due to intracranial tumor  hemorrhage and tumor  necrosis. See Appendix C, Table 
C-1 for a complete listing of possibly related SAEs. Seven (7) patients died during the course of 
the study because of  disease progression.

5.16 Study No. IIC RD EC -053 (completed, Anaplastic Astrocytoma and Glioblastoma 
Multiforme) . 
 
This was a multi -center, open -label phase I/II clinical study.  Patients were treated with 200 
mg of nimotuzumab once a week for 6 weeks concurrent with daily radiation 5 days a week for 
6 weeks. This study was conducted in 5 investigation sites in Cuba and it initiated in February 
2002 and completed in February 2005.  
Twenty -nine (29) patients were enrolled in the study, 13 males and 16 females with a mean 
age of 46 years (range 20 to 64 years). Patients with glioblastoma multiforme (16 patients), 
anaplastic astrocytoma (12 patients), and anaplastic oligodendroglioma (1  patient) were included 
in the study.  
There were 311 adverse events (AEs) reported in 18 patients (62.07%) during study period. 
Out of 311 AEs, there were 15 AEs reported in 7 patients (24.1%) that were considered to be 
related to study drug. The most common nimotuzumab -related AEs (> 2 subjec ts, 6.9%) were 
chills (4 subjects, 13. 8%), alanine aminotransferase out of range (3 subjects, 10.3 %) and nausea 
(2 subjects, 6.9 %). Related adverse events are summarized in Appendix B, Table B -16. 
In the study, there were 16 SAEs reported in 8 patients (27.6 %) who experienced serious 
adverse events during the study period, all of which were single events reported by no more than 
1 patient. None of the serious adverse events were considered by the i nvestigators to be related 
to nimotuzumab treatment. No patients discontinued due to adverse events. Nineteen (19) (66 %) 
patients died during  the study;  however, all these deaths were attributed to disease progression.  
Imaging  primary tumor s using computed tomography and MRI scans was conducted prior to 
inclusion, at week 8, at month 3 and every 3 months thereafter.  Tumor  response was evaluated 
using NCI RECIST.  Patients were followed for survival until death.  
In the ITT population (N=29), the best response was classified as follows: 5 patients (17.2 %) 
achieved CR, 6 patients (20.7 %) achieved PR. Objective response (CR+PR) was seen in 11 of 
29 patients included in the trial (37.9 %). Stable disease was the bes t response in 11 patients (37.9 
%). In 3 patients (10.3 %) the best response was PD. The remaining 4 patients were lost to follow 
up. The median overall survival time was 22.2 months,  and the median progression free survival 
time was 16.3 months.  
In the TTG population (N=24), 5 patients (20.8 %) achieved CR and 6 patients (25 %) 
achieved PR. Objective response (CR+PR) was seen in 11 of 24 evaluable patients included in 
the trial (45.8 %). The best response was evaluated as SD in 11 patients (45.8 % ). Only 1 patient 
(4.2 %) reported PD as his best response in this analysis,  and one patient was censored. The 
median overall survival time was 22.3 months,  and the median progression free survival time 
was 18.5 months.

(Confidential Information )         This was a Phase III, controlled, randomized, double blind study to evaluate the efficacy of 
nimotuzumab combined with radiotherapy compared to radiotherapy plus placebo in patients 
with high grade glioma. On the treatment arm patients were administered we ekly 200 mg 
nimotuzumab infusion for six weeks together with 60 Gy conventional radiotherapy and then 
maintenance dose of 200 mg nimotuzumab every 21 days during 1 year of treatment and on the 
control arm patients received weekly administration of 4 vials of placebo infusions for six weeks 
together with 60 Gy conventional radiotherapy and then maintenance of 4 vials of placebo every 
21 days until 1 year of treatment was completed. Primary endpoint  was to evaluate the efficacy 
with respect to survival in th e combined treatment humanized mAb anti -EGFR (nimotuzumab) 
and radiotherapy versus radiotherapy and placebo in patients with high grade gliomas and 
secondary endpoints were to evaluate the progression -free intervals in patients treated with the 
treatment p roposed in this study, evaluate the toxicity of nimotuzumab combined with 
radiotherapy in the study patients and determine the prognosis or prediction value of the 
expression of the EGFR on the effect of the study treatment. This study was conducted in 8 
investigation sites in Cuba, and it initiated in June 2005 and completed in June 2010.  
A total of 70 patients were included in the study. Thirty -two (32) patients on the nimotuzumab 
plus radiotherapy arm and 38 patients on the placebo plus radiotherapy arm.  
A total of 398 adverse events in 52 patients (185 AEs in 24 patients (75%) in the radiotherapy 
plus nimotuzumab arm and 213 AEs reported in 28 patients (73.7%) in the radiotherapy plus 
placebo arm) were reported independent of the causality. Out of 185 AEs  reported on the 
radiotherapy plus nimotuzumab arm there were 40 AEs reported in 9 patients (28.1%) on which 
the causality was assessed as possible or probably  related to the study drug. The most reported  
study drug -related AEs (> 2 subjects, 6.25%) were a lanine aminotransferase increase  (5 subjects, 
15.6%), anorexia (2 subjects, 6.25%), nausea (2 subjects, 6.25%), pyrexia (2 subjects, 6.25%), 
dizziness (2 subjects, 6.25%) and tremors (2 subjects, 6.25%). See Appendix B, Table B -17 for 
a complete listing of related AEs.  
There were 41 SAEs reported in 26 patients (13 SAEs reported in 6 patients (18.8%) in the 
radiotherapy plus nimotuzumab arm and 28 SAEs reported in 10 patients (26.3%) in the 
radiotherapy plus placebo arm) during the study period. Out of 13 SAEs in the rad iotherapy plus 
nimotuzumab arm, none of these SAEs were reported by the investigators to be related to the 
study drug.  
There were 44 patients who died during the course of the study, 17 from the radiotherapy plus 
nimotuzumab arm and 27 from the radiotherapy and placebo arm. In all cases, the investigators 
assessed the cause of death to be unrelated to study drug and due to  progressive disease.  
Median overall survival for patients treated with nimotuzumab plus radiotherapy was 17.76 
months compared to 12.63 months for patients of the placebo plus radiotherapy arm, with a HR 
= 0.64.

maintenance stage and extended maintenance stage. In the concomitant stage nimotuzumab was 
administered in combination with radiotherapy and temozolomide (75 mg/m2). Four weeks 
following the end of radiotherapy, the adjuvant stage began, which involved concomitant 
administration of nimotuzumab (200 mg) and temozolomide (150 – 200 mg/m2). Following 
completion of 6 cycles of temozolomide, patients were administered nimotuzumab  in the 
maintenance and extended maintenance phases until disease progression. Nimotuzumab was 
administered once weekly during the first 6 weeks of the trial, and every 3 weeks thereafter.  
A total of 56 patients were enrolled:  41 males (73.2 %) and 15 females (26.8 %) with a mean 
age of 51 years (range 22 to 70 years). All patients were assessed for safety and efficacy.  
In the study, there were 598 AEs reported in 51 patients (91.1%). Out of 598 AEs reported, 
there were 51 AEs reported in 9 patients (16.1%) that were considered to be related to the 
treatment of nimotuzumab, radiotherapy and chemotherapy. The most reported  study drug -
related AEs (> 2 subjects, 3.57%) were chills (4 subjects, 7.14%) and pyrexia (4 subjects, 7.14%). 
Most  AEs were mild or moderate in severity. See Appendix B, Table B -18 for a complete listing 
of related AEs.  
There were 50 SAEs reported in 28 patients (50.0 %) during the study period. Out 50 SAEs 
reported, only 1 SAE that consisted of stomatitis reported in 1 patient (1.79) was considered 
related to nimotuzumab. A listing of related SAEs is presented in Appendix C, Table C -1. 
During the trial, 1 patient withdrew due to an adverse event and 8 patients died while on study. 
None of the events reported as leading to death were assessed as related to study drug.

Median progression free survival was 9.3 months [95% CI: 5.5 - 11.2 months]. The objective 
response rate (ORR) [95% CI] at 12 months was 17.6 % [7.2 – 28.1 %] and 1 2.0 % [3.0, 21.0%]

% [14.2, 38.9%].  
 
5.19 Study No. OSAG -101-BSA -05 (completed GBM).  
 
This was a Phase III, open label, controlled randomized multicenter clinical study designed to 
assess efficacy of standard radiotherapy plus concomitant and adjuvant OSAG 101 (Theraloc®) 
(nimotuzumab) plus Temozolomide vs. standard radiotherapy plus concom itant and adjuvant 
Temozolomide in patient with newly diagnosed, histologically confirmed glioblastoma 
multiforme. Patients were treated with weekly nimotuzumab infusions (400 mg) for 12 weeks 
and then every two weeks until disease progression in combinati on with 6 weeks of radiotherapy 
and Temozolomide 75 mg/m2 per day for 7 days a week for 6 weeks then 150 -200 mg/m2 for 5 
days a week starting on Week 10 every 28 days. The primary objective of this clinical trial was 
to investigate the influence of treatme nt Arm A (standard radiotherapy plus concomitant and 
adjuvant OSAG 101 (Theraloc®) plus temozolomide) on the progression -free survival (PFS) 
compared to treatment Arm B (standard radiotherapy plus concomitant and adjuvant 
Temozolomide). The study was condu cted in 9 centers in Germany and it initiated in August 
2007 and completed in September 2010.  
In total, 149 adult male and female patients with newly diagnosed, histologically confirmed 
glioblastoma multiforme Grade IV were enrolled from 11 active study centers  in Germany. All 
patients were randomized (Arm A: n=75, Arm B: n=74), but seven patients were excluded from 
efficacy analyses due to discontinuation before start of therapy or major protocol violations. 
Therefore, 142 patients (Arm A: n=71, Arm B: n=71) we re analyzed for efficacy (FAS/PP) and 
safety.

B. On average, patients treated in Arm A were non -progressive for 7.7 months (235 days) 
compared to 5.8 months (178 days) in treatment Arm B. The progression -free survival (PFS) was 
not statistically significan t between Arm A and  Arm B. The subgroup of patients with non – 
methylated MGMT status showed a delta of 16.5 % for the 6 -months -PFS rate (6 -months PFS 
rate, Arm A: 63.3 % vs. Arm B: 46.9 %) but did not reach statistically  significant p (0.2125).  
The overall survival (OS) as secondary efficacy variable was longer in treatment Arm A 
compared to Arm B. However, this difference was not statistically significant. The RT + 
Temozolomide + Nimotuzumab arm (Arm A) reached 22.3 months median OS, and the med ian 
OS of 19.6 months with RT + Temozolomide (Arm B), with a p -value of 0.4856 and with a delta 
of 2.7 months (Stupp Protocol 1.7 months).  
All 142 patients enrolled who received at least one dose of the study medication were included

There were  64 SAEs reported in 28 patients (39.4%) on radiotherapy , chemotherapy and

The most common related to the study drug SAEs (> subjects, 2.82%) were  leukopenia (2

2.82%). A listing of related SAEs is presented in Appendix C , Table C -1. 
There were seven cases of death documented as SAEs related to the underlying disease. In no

5.22 Study No. BT-NI-GL-1 (completed, Glioma  Adult ). 
 
This was a Phase I, non-randomized, open -label, dose -escalation clinical design , single center  
study to  evaluate the tolerability and early effectiveness of nimotuzumab combined with 
radiotherapy and chemotherapy in the treatment of malignant glioma, and to recommend dosing 
regimens for later clinical studies .  
The p rimary endpoint of the study was the tolerability of nimotuzumab combined with 
corresponding standard radiotherapy and chemotherapy regimens for newly treated malignant 
glioma , and secondary endpoints were disease -free survival (DFS) and overall survival (OS). For 
Nimotuzumab Investigator’s Brochure  Confidential

(Confidential Information )         the evaluation of tolerability and safety of nimotuzumab  in the combination therapy , the 
corresponding standard radiotherapy and chemotherapy regimens and doses  were fixed , and a 
dose escalation approach was adopted to gradually increase the dose level of nimotuzumab . 
Radiotherapy started 2 to 4 weeks after surgery, with a radiation dose of 2Gy per day, 5 days 
a week, for a total of 6 weeks, with a total radiation dose of 60Gy . Temozolomide was 
administered simultaneously with radiation at a dose of 75 mg/m²/d, 7 days a week × 6 cycles . 
Patients who received Carmustine (BCNU)  as chemotherapy , were administered at a dose of 80 
mg/m2 /d, 1 day per week × 8 weeks.  Nimotuzumab was administered in three groups of patients 
receiving 100mg, 200mg and 400mg/week, 3 cases/group. The drug was administered 
intravenously. The infusion time was no less than 60 minutes, once a week, a total of 6 times.  
The study evaluated first the lower dose , and e ach dose was always infused before chemotherapy 
and radiotherapy.  This study initiated in April 2011 and completed in June 2013. There were 3 
cases in the 100  mg group, 3 cases in the 200  mg group, and 3 cases in the 400  mg group. All 
subjects completed the trial medication, and no patient terminated treatment due to treatment - 
related adverse events . 
As of the cut -off date of follow -up on May 27, 2013, 3 cases died, 2 cases were alive, and 4 
cases were lost to follow -up. The median DFS was 10.53 months,  and the median OS was 20.10. 
months.  
In th e safety analysis , nimotuzumab combined with radiotherapy and chemotherapy failed to 
reach the maximum tolerated dose (MTD) for the treatment of malignant glioma, with low (100 
mg/w), medium (200 mg/w), and high doses (400 mg/w) being well tolerated. No serious or 
important adverse events occurred.  
Adverse events occurred in 8 of all 9 patients enrolled in the study, with an incidence rate of  
88.9%; including 11 cases of adverse events in the blood/bone marrow system (57.9%); 2 
cases in the skin system (10.5%); and 3 cases in the urinary system (15.8%); systemic symptoms 
in 2 cases (10.5%); gastrointestinal tract in 1 case (5.2%). A listing of treatment -related adverse 
events is provided in Appendix B, Table B -22. 
The common adverse events related or possibly related to nimotuzumab included leukopenia 
(6 cases /time), urinary occult blood (3 cases /time), neutropenia (1 case), platelet count decreased 
(1 case), rash (1 case), AST increased (1 case), ALT increased (1  case). All adverse events 
recorded were classified as grade 1-2 according to CTCAE3.0. No adverse events of grade 3 or 
above occurred, no serious adverse events were observed, no subjects withdrew from the study 
due to adverse events, and no deaths occurr ed during the study period.  
In terms of laboratory tests: a total of 14 laboratory test abnormalities occurred in the study, 
including 6 cases of leukopenia, 1 leukocyte increase, 1 neutrophil decrease, 1 platelet decrease, 
and 3 cases of urinary occult blood and ALT. One case each with elevated AST enzyme. There 
were 13 cases of abnormal laboratory test indicators related to nimotuzumab, and the adverse 
event grades were all grade 1 -2. Among them, 6 cases had a decrease in white blood cells, 1 case 
had a decrease in neutr ophils, 1 ca se had a decrease in platelets, and 3 cases had positive urinary 
occult blood.  
From the safety data obtained in this study, nimotuzumab combined with radiotherapy and 
chemotherapy in the treatment of malignant glioma failed to reach the maximum tolerated dose 
(MTD)  evaluated at  low (100mg/w), medium (200mg/w),  and high (400 mg/w) doses.  The high 
dose (400 mg/w) was tolerable, and the adverse events observed in the study were all grade 1 -2; 
no serious adverse events or unexpected adverse events occurred.

(Confidential Information )         Patients with locally advanced squamous head and neck squamous cell carcinomas were 
enrolled in a two -arm, randomized, open -label, Phase III trial to investigate the efficacy and 
toxicity of addition of Nimotuzumab during concurrent chemoradiation. The pri mary objective 
is to determine the PFS at 2 years and the secondary objective is the locoregional response ( LCR ) 
at 24 weeks  from visit of randomization , locoregional control at 2 years, OS, quality of life and 
safety. After the subjects fulfilled all the eligibility criteria were stratified on the basis of T -group 
(T0,1,2 vs T3,4), N -group (N0,1 vs N2,3), site ( oropharynx versus non oropharynx), technique 
of radiation (conventional versus others) and randomized in 1:1 ratio to receive chemoradiation 
(CRT arm) or Nimotuzumab plus chemoradiation (NCRT arm). In both arms, cisplatin was dosed 
30 mg/m2 weekly for 7 weeks and total 66 -70 Gy over a period of 6.5 -7 weeks. In study arm, 
Nimotuzumab was administered 200 mg weekly for 7 weeks. The median duration of f ollow up 
was 39.13 months (39.5 months in the CRT arm and 39.0 months in the NCRT arm). This trial 
was initiated in 2012 and completed enrollment in 2018.  
A total of 536 patients with histologically confirmed squamous cell carcinoma of head and 
neck in stage III/IVA,  B with KPS >70 was included in the study. Two hundred and sixty -eight 
(268) patients (mean age 54years) were randomized to control arm, and 268 patients (mean age 
55 years) were randomized to the study arm. No significant differences were detected between 
the two arms regarding demography or tumor  characteristics.  
Most common grade 3 -5 AEs observed were mucositis, radiation dermatitis, odynophagia 
and dysphagia. Addition of Nimotuzumab to chemoradiation did not produce additional toxicity 
except grade 3 -5 mucositis which was significantly higher in study arm. A listing of treatment -
related adverse events is provided in Appendix B, Table B -23. 
Two hundred thirty -five patients experienced disease progression, including 134 in the 
control arm and 101 in the study arm. The sites of progression in the CRT arm were 
locoregional in 105 patients (39.2%), distant in 24 patients (9%) and both in 5 patients (1.9%). 
The corresponding sites of progression in the NCRT study arm were locoregional in 70 patients 
(26.1%), distant in 20 patients (7.5%), and both in 11 patients (4.1%).  
The addition of nimotuzumab significantly improved the PFS (HR 0.69; 95% CO, 0.53 -
0.89; P = .004) . The 2 -year follow for PFS was 61.8% (95% CI, 55.2 – 67.7) in the NCRT arm 
and 50.1% (95% CI, 43.7 – 56.2) in the CRT arm.  The addition of nimotuzumab led to a 
consistent benefit across all subgroups.  
The addition of nimotuzumab decreased the hazard of the disease recurrence by 29% (HR 
0.71; 95% CI, 0.55 – 0.92; P=0.008 ). The 2 -year DFS was 60.2% ; 95% CI, 53.6% - 66.3%)  in 
the NCRT arm compared with the CRT arm ( 48.5% ; 95% CI, 42.1% - 54.7%) . 
The increment in PFS from the addition of nimotuzumab was because of a decrease in the 
locoregional failures (P=0.006). The 2 -year locoregional control rate was significantly better 
in the NCRT arm (67.5%; 95% CI, 60.9% - 73.3%)  than in the CRT arm (57.6%; 95% CI, 
50.9% - 63.6%). The addition of nimotuzumab led to a 33% reduction (HR, 0.67; 95% CI, 0.50 
– 0.89; P=0.006) in the risk of locoregional failure, and the reduction was consistent across all 
subg roups.  
There were 128 deaths in the CRT arm and 113 in the NCRT arm (HR 0.84; 95 CI, 0.65 – 
1.08; P=0.163) , therefore the addition of nimotuzumab had a trend towards improved OS in 
the study arm compared to control arm . The 2 -year OS was 63.8% (95 CI, 57.3% - 69.6%) and 
57.7% (95% CI, 51.3% - 63.6%) in the NCRT and CRT arms, respectively.  
For objective responses post -chemoradiation, there were evaluable 239 patients (89.2%) in 
the CRT arm and 233 patients (86.9%) in the NCRT arm (P=0.424). The overall response 
among evaluable patients was 89.1 -5 (n = 123) in the CRT arm versus 89.3% (n = 208) in the 
NCRT arm. A complete response post -treatment completion was documented in 62.7 -5 of 
patients in the CRT arm (n = 168) and in 61.6% of patients (n =  165) in the NCRT arm.

(Confidential Information )         Salvage surgery for residual disease was planned in the multidisciplinary clinic for 72 
patients, including 34 in the CRT arm and 38 in the NCRT arm. Of the 34 patients in the CRT 
arm, 22 underwent salvage surgery, 5 progressed before salvage surgery, and 7 patients refused 
surgery. The 26 salvage surger ies performed were lymph node dissection in 13 patients, local 
excision in 1 patient, and both local excision and neck lymph node dissection in 12 patients.  
There was a significant interaction between HPV status and treatment outcomes. The HR 
for PFS in p16 -negative oropharyngeal cancer was 0.54 (95% CI, 0.36 – 0.79), whereas HR for 
p16-positive cancers was 2.6 (95% CI, 0.57 – 11.9). the 2 -year PFS was 31.5% ( 95% CI, 21.5% 
- 42.0%) in the CRT arm and 57.2% (95% CI, 45.8% - 67.1%) in the NCRT arm in patients 
with p16 -negative oropharyngeal cancer (P = 0.001). A similar higher magnitude of benefit 
was observed regarding  DFS (HR , 0.55; 95% CI, 0.37 – 0.82; P = 0.0 06), LRC (HR, 0.61; 95% 
CI, 0.4 – 0.94; P = 0.024), and OS (HR, 0.63; 95% CI, 0.43 – 0.92; P = 0.018. The 2 -year OS 
was o.39% (95% CI, 28.3% - 49.6%) in the CRT arm and 57.6% (95% CI, 46.3% - 67.4%) in 
the NCRT arm in patients with p16 -negative oropharyngeal cancers.   
The analysis for 2 years  showed that nimotuzumab in combination with CRT was superior 
to CRT alone in improving the PFS. The NCRT led to a significant  increase in  the LRC and 
DFS compared to CRT alone.  
A new analysis of the clinical data of the study was subsequently done and presented at the 
Annual Meeting of the American Society of Clinical Oncology (ASCO) Meeting 20 24 to 
follow up the long -term survival  of patients in this study . The primary endpoint was a 10 -year 
OS; the key secondary endpoint was late adverse events. Intent to treat analysis was performed. 
Landmark analysis was performed to compare 10 OS between the 2 arms. COX proportional 
hazard model will be used for the calculation of ha zard ratio (HR). The adverse events between 
the 2 arms were compared using a Fisher’s test. A p -value of 0.05 will be considered as 
significant. The median follow -up was 8.86 years (95% CI 8.59 -9.16).  
The primary site of the primary was the oropharynx (269,50.2%) and only 24 cases were 
HPV positive. The 10 -year OS was 22.5% (95% CI 16.7 -28.8) versus 33.5% (95% CI 27.6 -
39.4) in the CRT and NCRT arm respectively (H R=0.811; 95%CI , 0.664  - 0.995 , P=0.044). 
The median OS was 2.78 years (95% CI , 2.31 - 3.69) versus 3.69 years (95% CI , 2.90 - 4.49) 
in the CRT and NCRT arm respectively (P=0.04).  
The median OS in HPV negative oropharynx was 1.8 years (95% CI , 1.51-2.09) versus 2.48 
years (95% CI , 1.79-3.16) in the CRT and NCRT arm respectively (P=0.02; HR 0.724 95%  CI, 
0.546 -0.959).  
Long -term adverse events were captured in 380 patients. There was no statistically 
significant difference in late -term adverse events between the 2 arms.  
This new analysis showed that t he addition of nimotuzumab to weekly cisplatin leads to 
improvement in long -term overall survival in locally advanced HNSCC without any additional 
increase in late -term adverse events. These results are largely applicable in HPV -negative 
patients.

in a non -randomized, open -label, Phase I/II trial to investigate the safety and efficacy of 
nimotuzumab treatment in combination with radiotherapy. Patients were divid ed into 4 cohorts 
and were administered 50, 100, 200, or 400 mg of nimotuzumab once weekly by intravenous 
infusion over a period of 30 minutes for 6 weeks. Radiotherapy consisted of 2 Gy doses daily, 5

Fourteen (14) patients, 3 women and 11 men (mean age 62, range 47 -78) were enrolled in the 
study.  Two patients discontinued therapy prior to receiving all 6 doses of nimotuzumab and were

In the safety data set of the study there was a total of 103 AEs reported in 14 patients (100%) 
during the study period. Out of 103 AEs reported, 51 AEs reported in 11 patients (78.6%) were 
assessed as probable, possibly  or definite related to the administration of radiotherapy and 
nimotuzumab. The most common related to the study drug AEs (> 3 subjects, 21.4%) were 
pyrexia (7 subjects, 50%), tremors (5 subjects, 35.7%), myalgia (4 subjects, 28.6%), anemia (3 
subjects, 21.4%), headache (3 subjects, 21.4%) a nd hypertension (3 subjects, 21.4%). A list of 
related AEs is summarized in Appendix B, Table B -24. 
There were no SAEs reported during the period of the study and there were no 
discontinuations due to adverse events. Seven (7) patients died during follow -up, however, none 
of the deaths were related to nimotuzumab treatment.  
The clinical response was classified according to the WHO criteria as CR, PR, SD, and PD. 
Imaging trials were performed before including the patient in the trial, at the end of the treatment 
with nimotuzumab combined with radiotherapy (week 6) and then eve ry 3 months thereafter 
(months 3, 6, 9, and 12).  
Results showed that the best therapeutic response was obtained at the highest dosage levels 
(200 and 400 mg) and due to the small sample size no statistically significant differences were 
observed between the 200 and 400 mg doses regarding response.  
 
5.25 Study No. IIC RD EC -046 (completed, SCCHN)  
  
This was a non -randomized, open -label Phase I/II clinical trial conducted in patients with 
advanced squamous cell carcinoma of the head and neck to investigate the safety, efficacy, and 
pharmacokinetic profile of nimotuzumab treatment in combination with r adiotherapy. Patients 
were enrolled in one of two treatment cohorts of 5 patients each. Patients received a single dose 
of nimotuzumab (200 or 400 mg) once a week for 6 weeks, for a cumulative dose of 1200 or 
2400 mg per treatment period. Patients also rec eived concurrently either 60 or 66 Gy radiotherapy 
once a day (5 days/week) for 6 weeks.  This study was conducted in one investigation site in 
Cuba,  and it initiated in November 2000 and completed in March 2002.  
Ten (10) male patients, with a mean age of 59 years (range 46 to 68), were enrolled in the 
study.  
In the safety data  of the study there was a total of 38 AEs reported in 9 patients (90%) during 
the study period. Out of 38 SAEs reported, 21 SAEs reported in 9 patients (90%) were assessed 
as probable, possible or definite related to the administration of radiotherapy and nimotuzumab. 
The most common reported study drug related to  AEs (> 2 subjects, 20 %) were tremors (4 
subjects, 40%), anemia (3 subjects, 30%), and hematuria (2 subjects, 20%). A list of related AEs 
is provided in Appendix B, Table B -25. 
There was 3 SAE reported in 1 patient (10%) during the study period. These 3 SAEs were 
assessed by the investigator to be related to the administration of nimotuzumab. The SAEs 
consisted of anemia , increased blood creatinine and hematuria . A list of these related SAEs is 
summarized in Appendix C, Table C -1. 
No patients withdrew from the study due to adverse events. Five (5) patients died during 
follow -up; all deaths were due to disease progression.

5.26 Study No. IIC RD EC -076 (completed, SCCHN).  
 
This was a Phase I, single center study to evaluate the pharmacodynamic effect of 
nimotuzumab in patients with advanced head and neck cancer in conjunction with radiation 
therapy. All patients were enrolled in one investigation site in Cuba. This study initiated in 
August 2005 and completed in November 2006.  
Ten (10) patients were enrolled in the study. The study population consisted of 8 males and 2 
females with a mean age of 63 years (range 53 to 73 years).  The patients were assigned in 
sequential manner to the two treatment groups, each receiving 8 doses o f nimotuzumab.  The 
first 5 patients received a 200  mg dose of nimotuzumab,  and the following 5 patients received a 
400mg dose of nimotuzumab.  
A total of 6 a dverse events were reported in 3 patients (30%) of the 10 patients included in the 
study. There was a total of 6 AEs reported in 3 patients (30 %). Out of 6 AEs reported, 4 AEs in 
3 patients (30%) were assessed by the investigators to be related to the administration of 
nimotuzumab. The related AEs included pyrexia, chills and aller gy. List of related AEs are 
provided in Appendix B, Table B -26.  
There were 2 SAEs reported in one patient (10%) during the study period. The SAEs were 
acute heart failure and respiratory sepsis. None of these SAEs were  assessed by the investigator 
to be related to the study drug.  
The combined therapy of nimotuzumab and radiation therapy resulted in objective anti -tumor 
response in 90% of patients.  There was no significant difference in survival time of patients 
treated with 200 mg or 400 mg doses of nimotuzumab (medians of 12.5 months vs. 5.8 months, 
respectively). Nimotuzumab was well tolerated in the study. The signal ing associated with 
nimotuzumab was not inhibited in the skin or in the tumor .  The proliferative activity was reduced 
after one dose of the study drug.  No perivasc ular lymphocytic inflammatory infiltrate was 
observed in the dermis.

nimotuzumab in conjunction with radiotherapy in patients with advanced (unresectable)

59 years (range 36 to 75 years).  Fourteen (14) patients were enrolled into the 100 mg dose group,  
and 17 patients were enrolled into the 200 mg dose group.

with advanced [Stage III or IVA (T1 -T4a, N0 -N2, excluding T4b)], histologic ally documented

nimotuzumab arm, compared to 26.1 for the RT alone arm and was 56.5 % for the CT + RT + 
nimotuzumab compared to 26.1 % for the CT + RT arm. The differ ences were statistically 
significant.  
 
5.30 Study No. CLG16/BIO009/SCCHN/hR3/2006 (completed, Head & Neck).  
 
This was a Phase IV, open -label, multicenter study to assess the safety and tolerability of 
nimotuzumab with standard of care (chemotherapy and/or radiotherapy).  Patients received 
weekly 200 mg administrations of nimotuzumab for 6 weeks in combination wit h a standard of 
care regimen. The study was initiated in November 2006 and completed in January 2009.  
One hundred fifty (150) patients were enrolled in the study. The patients consisted of 107 
males and 43 females with a mean age of 55 years (range 4 to 87 years). One hundred five (105) 
patients (70.0 %) were treated with nimotuzumab plus chemotherapy and radiotherapy, 25 
patients (16.7 %) were treated with nimotuzumab plus radiotherapy, 19 patients (12.7 %) were 
treated with nimotuzumab plus chemotherapy and the remaining patient was treated with 
nimotuzumab monotherapy).  
In the safety data set of the study there was a total of 75 AEs reported in 36 patients (24.0%). 
Out of 75 AEs reported, 9 AEs reported in 6 patients (4.0 %) were assessed by the investigators 
to be probable, possible or definite related to the treatment o f chemotherapy, radiotherapy and 
nimotuzumab. The events reported  related to the study drug were  skin rash (2 subjects, 1.3%), 
hypotension (1 subject, 0.7%), pruritus (1 subject, 0.7%), pyrexia (1 subject, 0.7%), rash (1 
subject, 0.7%), and rash vesicular (1 subject, 0.7%). A listing of related to study drug AEs is 
summarized in Appendix B, Table B -30.  
There were 4 SAEs reported in 4 patients (2.67%). None of the SAEs assessed  by the 
investigators was related to the administration of the study drug.  
There was no efficacy parameters investigated in this study.

5.32 Study No. M9/CIMAB/AEC -04 (completed, Head and Neck).  
 
This was a phase IV study conducted in advanced head and neck newly diagnosed and 
recurrent cancer patients to evaluate safety and efficacy of nimotuzumab. Four therapeutic 
schemes were evaluated: nimotuzumab, nimotuzumab  + Chemotherapy (Nimo  + CT), 
nimotuzumab  + Radiotherapy (Nimo  + RT) and nimotuzumab  + Chemo  + Radiotherapy (Nimo  
+ RT/CT). Common Toxicity Criteria to Evaluate Adverse Events (AEs) (version 3.0) was used 
to classify AEs; Kaplan -Meier curves were compared by the non -parametric Log -rank metho d 
and Cox regression was applied for subgroup analyses. This study initiated in November 2012 
and completed in November 2014. A total of 225 patients were included.  
Most AEs were classified as grade I, AEs related to the product were reported in 36 patients. 
In this subgroup, most frequent events were anemia, leukopenia, neutropenia, anorexia, nausea, 
vomiting, asthenia and fever. In the newly diagnosed subset (n=155) , although no significant 
difference was shown in the intent -to-treat (ITT) analysis, there was a trend toward a benefit in 
favor of Nimo  + RT/CT . The benefit was  not just related to Progression -Free-Survival (PFS) 
(22.4 months; p=0.065), but also to Overa ll Survival (OS) (24.3 months; p=0.089), with higher 
survival rates at 12 and 24 months for PFS (67.3% and 46.3%, respectively) and OS (70.1% and 
50.3%, respectively), compared to the other regimens. A listing of related to study drug AEs is 
summarized in Appendix B, Table B -32. 
There was a total of 946 SAEs (114 SAEs on nimotuzumab arm, 66 SAEs on radiotherapy 
plus nimotuzumab arm, 112 SAEs on nimotuzumab  plus chemotherapy, and 624 SAEs on 
chemotherapy concomitant with radiotherapy and nimotuzumab arm) reported in 131 patients. 
Of the 946 SAEs reported, 117 SAEs (12.4%) were assessed by the investigators to be probable,

5.33 Study No. BPL -Nimo -SCCHN -RWS -1 (completed, Head and Neck).  
 
This was a multicenter, retrospective, observational study design based on real -world data. 
The study was conducted in 8 public hospitals across China that use nimotuzumab injections 
relatively intensively and collect patients who received chemoradiotherap y/radiotherapy ± 
nimotuzumab injection for the treatment of locally advanced head and neck carcinoma from 
January 2015 to December 2018. Clinical data and the survival follow -up data of patients 
included in the study were analyzed to evaluate effectiveness  of nimotuzumab combined with 
chemoradiotherapy/radiotherapy in the treatment of locally advanced head and neck squamous 
cell carcinoma. All individual adverse drug reactions collected in China from January 2015 to 
December 2018 were used for safety evalua tion. The study initiated in July 2021 and concluded 
in January 2023.  
Patients in the study group received nimotuzumab combined with 
chemoradiotherapy/radiotherapy. Nimotuzumab was administered at least 5 times during 
radiotherapy administration ± 7 days. The control group received only 
chemoradiation/radiotherapy and nimotuzumab was not used at least 7 days before and 7 days 
after chemoradiation/radiotherapy administration.  
The primary endpoint of the study was to use real-world data to evaluate the effectiveness and 
safety of nimotuzumab combined with chemoradiotherapy/radiotherapy in the treatment of 
locally advanced head and neck squamous cell carcinoma. The secondary endpoints were to 
explore the characteristics of the patients who benefit more from nimotuzumab and discover the 
advantageous groups. Efficacy evaluation analysis included: 3 -year overall survival (OS) rate, 3 -
year progression -free survival (PFS) rate, 3 -year local control (LRC) rate, objective response rate 
(ORR), and disease control rate (DCR).  
The original design planned to enroll  a total of 1,900 cases, with 475 cases in the study group 
and 1,425 cases in the control group , with at least 266 cases in each group a fter matching 
according to 1:1 propensity score (PS). In fact, 2 ,250 cases , out of the 25.442 screened cases, 
were initially introduced in t he data collection . The total number of successfully s elected cases 
was 1,931 cases, including 308 cases in the research group and 1 .623 cases in the control group. 
After matching according to 1:1 propensity score  (PS), there were 612 patients included in the 
study, 306 cases in the study group and 306 cases in the control group. During the study, were 
collected a total of 151 post -marketing reports were collected from the period between Januar y 
2015  and December 2018  and included in the safety analysis.  
The median follow -up was 51.88 (48.36~55.95) months and 54.80 (50.33~58.15) months  in 
the experimental group and the control group,  respectively. The study group had 96 death events , 
and the control group had 117 death events. The median survival time (OS) of both groups was 
not reach ed during the study . The 3 -year OS rate of the nimotuzumab group was 74.6%, and 
63.3%  in the control group ( non-stratified Log -rank test, P=0.038, using the non -stratified Cox 
proportional hazards model, the HR (95% CI) was 0.7 5 (0.57 – 0.99) . 
The median PFS of the study group increased 10.91 months compared to the control group 
(40.77 months vs 29.86 months). (non-stratified Log -rank test, P=0.021), using cloglog 
transformation P=0.009, HR (95% CI) = 0.74 ; (0.58 – 0.96); therefore, with a 26% of reduction 
in risk progression in the nimotuzumab group. The 3 -year PFS rate of the nimotuzumab group 
was 57.7%, and the 3 -year PFS rate of the control group was 44.3%  
The 3 -year LRC rate of nimotuzumab group and the control group were similar (95.7% vs 
93.9%), non -stratified Log -rank test p=0.560; using clolog transformation method: p=0.540, HR 
(95% CI) = 0.72 (0.25, 2.14).

(p=1.00). The DCR of the nimotuzumab group and the control group were similar (57.2% vs 
55.9%. The nimotuzumab group was 1.3% non -significantly higher than the control grou p (p =

From January 1, 2015,  to December 31, 2018, a total of 24,976 cases were expected to receive

were received from  patients using nimotuzumab, and 146 (0.6%)  were r elated to the drug . The 
main adverse reactions were systemic diseases and various reactions at the site of  administration 
(69 cases, 0.3%) and gastrointestinal system dis orders  (19 cases, 0. 1%), chills (31 cases, 0.1%), 
fever (17 cases, 0.1%) . A listing of related  study drug AEs is summarized in Appendix B, Table

on these nimotuzumab related SAE is listed in Appendix C, Table C -1. 
In summary, post-matching data analysis from this study shows that nimotuzumab combined 
with concurrent chemoradiotherapy/radiotherapy is effective in the treatment of locally advanced 
head and neck cancer. Patients treated with nimotuzumab had significant survival  benefits  and a 
better 3 -year PFS compared to control group. No significant differences were observed for 3 -
year LRC, ORR and DCR  between nimotuzumab and the control group. Safety results indicate 
that nimotuzumab has a favorable safety profile.  
 
 
5.34 Study No. IIC RD EC -084 (completed, Hepatic Carcinomas).  
 
This was a Phase I, open -label, single arm, escalating dose safety study of immune -
chemoembolization using nimotuzumab in patients with hepatocellular carcinoma to determine 
the maximum tolerated dose or optical biological dose of nimotuzumab to be used fo r immune -
chemoembolization. Fifteen  patients received 50, 100, 200 or 400 mg of nimotuzumab in 
combination with 25 to 50 mg/m2 of doxorubicin and 10 mL lipidol by intra-arterial  
administration. Primary endpoint was to determine maximum tolerated dose and s econdary 
endpoint were overall response rate, overall survival and duration of the response. This study 
was initiated in April 2007 and completed in July 2009.   
A total of 15 patients were included, 3 patients at the dose of 50 mg, 3 at 100 mg, 8 at 200 mg 
and 1 patient at 400 mg dose of nimotuzumab.  
A total of 25 adverse events in 6 patients were reported independent of the causality. Of the 
25 events, there were 12 events (48.0 %) associated with the administration of doxorubicin, 5 
(20.0 %) associated with the arteriographic procedure, 2 (8.0 %) wit h the embolization, 1 (4.0 
%) associated with nimotuzumab, 2 (8.0 %) other causes and 2 (8.0 %) no related to the 
administered drugs. Only in 1 event was the causality  assessed as possible or probable related to 
the study drug which was a cutaneous rash in one patient. The most frequently reported AEs, 
regardless of relationship to the study drug, were anorexia, hematoma on the injection site and 
hematuria. See Appendix B, Table B -34 for a listing of related AEs. No serious adverse events 
were reported.  
After a single dose of 50, 100, 200 or 400 mg of nimotuzumab in combination with 
doxorubicin via intraarterial administration the overall survival of the patients was 13.01 months.

(Confidential Information )         This was a Phase II randomized, open -label, multi -center trial that recruited patients with 
locally advanced nasopharyngeal squamous cell carcinomas from 7 centers in China.  The safety 
and short -term efficacy of nimotuzumab treatment was assessed as an ad junctive therapy to 
radiotherapy.  A total of 137 patients were enrolled in the study and were divided into 2 cohorts 
comprised of nimotuzumab treatment plus radiotherapy (n = 70), or radiotherapy alone (n = 67).  
Nimotuzumab treatment consisted of a 100 m g dose of nimotuzumab administered once a week 
for 8 weeks concomitantly with radiotherapy, which consisted of 2 Gy doses administered daily, 
5 days/week (equivalent to a total of 70 to 76 Gy of radiotherapy).  This trial was conducted 
between August 2002 and October 2004.  
A total of 137 patients ranging in age from 18 to 70 years, were enrolled in the study.  Of these 
patients, 126 were included in the Per Protocol (PP) population (all protocol -compliant patients), 
and 130 were in the ITT population. All patients were asses sed for safety.  
In the safety data set (N=137), the most common adverse reaction related to nimotuzumab 
was fever, with an incidence of 4.28 %. The highest temperature as recorded was 39 ºC, which 
resolved with the administration of antipyretics. Dizziness and hypotension  were observed in 
2.86 % of patients, with the lowest pressure documented at 80/50 mmHg. Skin rash and nausea, 
each observed in 1.43 % of patients, were mild and resolved spontaneously. These nimotuzumab -
related adverse events were all generally mild in se verity. A list of related AEs is provided in 
Appendix B, Table B -35. No serious adverse events were reported.  
The efficacy of treatment with nimotuzumab was assessed at the end of the treatment period, 
and again at 5 and 17 weeks after the end of treatment using the WHO criteria to evaluate tumor  
response. No additional cancer treatments were administered during this evaluation period.  
Overall, the complete response rate was significantly better in the nimotuzumab group plus 
radiotherapy compared to radiotherapy alone at the end of the treatment period and 5 and 17 
weeks after the end of treatment.  Overall respon se, which includes both complete response and 
partial response rates, was also significantly better in the nimotuzumab group compared to the 
radiotherapy group [100 % in the nimotuzumab group in both the ITT and PP populations, 
compared to 92.31 % and 90.9 1 % in the radiotherapy group (PP and ITT, respectively)].  
Additionally, distant metastases were evaluated at 17 weeks post -treatment and were detected in 
5 control patients, but in only 1 nimotuzumab -treated patient.  The difference, however, was not 
statistically significant due to the low number of patients and short follow -up period.  
 
 
5.36 Study No. BT-CT-001 (completed, Nasopharyngeal).  
 
This was a  randomized, double -blinded controlled, and multicenter phase III clinical trial. 
Patients included had histologically confirmed diagnosis of locally advanced NPC, staging III or 
IVa according to China NPC staging system 2008 version and with measurable primary tumor, 
aged 18 -70 years, Karnofsky performance status (KPS)>70, more than 6 months survival time 
and enough organ function. All patients were randomly assigned (3:1) to receive nimotuzumab 
plus chemo -radiotherapy (intensity -modulated radiation therapy or conformal radiotherapy), 
cisplatin, three cycles) (arm A) or placebo plus chemo -radiotherapy (arm B ).  
The primary endpoint of the study was overall survival (OS) rate at 5 years. Secondary 
endpoints included the objective response rate (ORR), disease control rate (DCR), 3 -year distant 
metastasis rate (DMR), 3 -year disease -free survival (DFS), 3 -year loco -regional control (LRC) 
rate and safety.  
A total of 482 patients in 24 study sites were enrolled (361 in arm A vs. 121 in arm B) from 
October 30, 2009, to January 25, 2022 . The entire study was divided into two phases. The first 
phase summarized the local tumor control rate and safety within 4 months after the subject's 
Nimotuzumab Investigator’s Brochure  Confidential

(Confidential Information )         enrollment, treatment and treatment completion. This period started when subjects signed the 
informed consent form (entering the screening period) and finished 4 months after the treatment 
ended. The second stage was a regular follow -up observation to summ arize long -term 
observation indicators. The time limit was considered when the last patient was followed up for 
5 years after enrollment.  
In both groups, patients received radiation therapy concurrent with Cisplatin -based 
chemotherapy. Radiation therapy was administered either as intensity -modulated radiation 
therapy (IMRT) or conventional conformal radiation therapy (CRT). IMRT in patients with 
nasopharynx cancer were radiated 30 -34 times, 2.20 -2.30Gy/time, once a day, 5 days a week, for 
6-7 weeks. GTV: 66 -78.2Gy, CTV1: 60 -64Gy, CTV2: 54 -60Gy. Patients with neck cancer, node -
positive, were radiated GTV total dose 60 -70Gy, once a day, 5 days a week, for 6 to 7 weeks, 
while node -negative patients received a CTV total dose 50 -55Gy, once a day, 5 days a week, for 
6 to 7 weeks. For CRT modality, patients with nasopharynx cancer received a total dose of 70 -
(76-80) Gy, 35 -(38-40) fractions, 2Gy/fraction, once a day, 5 days/week, for 6 -8 weeks. If there 
was residual disease at the end of treatment, the dose was increased as appropriate. For patients 
with neck cancer, lymph node positive: 64 -70Gy, 32 -35 fractions, 2Gy/fraction, once a day, 5 
days/week,  for 6 -7 weeks. In the lymph node negative subgroup, 50 -56Gy, 25 -28 fractions, 
2Gy/fraction, once a day, 5 days/week, for 5 -6 weeks.  
Chemotherapy was administered according to the individual differences in the patient's 
tolerance to cisplatin, one of the following two chemotherapy regimens was selected. The first 
cisplatin dose was guaranteed to reach 100 mg/m2, and the cisplatin administration method of 
each cycle before and after is consistent: (1). Cisplatin (DDP): 100 mg/m2, given once a day, 21 
days as a cycle, for 2 to 3 cycles, started simultaneously with radiotherapy, or (2). DDP: total 
dose 100 mg/m2, administered in 3 divided d oses, 21 days as a cycle, for 2 to 3 cycles, started 
simultaneously with radiotherapy.  
In addition, patients were randomized to receive either nimotuzumab injection 
(Taixinsheng®) or placebo. Nimotuzumab was administered in the experimental arm as 
intravenous infusion, 200 mg/ week, once a week for 7 -8 weeks.  
In the F ull Analysis Set (FAS)  population, the median follow -up time for the experimental 
group and the control group was 75.7 (74.1 -78.2) months and 73.6 (71.4 -75.9) months, 
respectively. The median survival time of both groups was not reached.  
The 5 -year overall survival (OS) rate of the experimental group was 76.9% (72.2% -80.9%), 
and that of the control group was 64.3% (55.1% -72.2%), meaning the addition of nimotuzumab 
to CCRT provided 12.6% absolute survival benefit at 5 -year (p=0.042; HR=0.64 6; 95% CI: 
0.449 -0.928) , P=0.018 . The risk of death in the experimental group was 35% lower than that in 
the control group, which was statistically significant.  
In the Per Protocol Set (PPS) population, the 5 -year OS rate in the experimental group was 
74.7% (69.3% -79.4%), and in the control group it was 64.3% (54.0% -72.9%, meaning 10.4% 
higher in the experimental group, compared to the control group (p= 0.183). The difference was 
clinically significant but not statistically significant. The inconsistency of results between the 
PPS population and the FAS population may  be related to the low statistical power caused by the 
3:1 randomization and the low sample size of  the PPS population. The results of survival analysis 
are usually based on the results of the FAS population.  
Secondary endpoints of the study were not met, since the objective response rate, disease 
control rate, 5 -year disease -free survival and 3 -year loco -regional recurrence free survival were 
not significantly different between two arms.  
In the FAS population, 207 cases of complete remission (CR), 109 cases of partial remission 
(PR), 8 cases of stable disease (SD), 6 cases of progressive disease (PD), and 31 cases of 
unevaluable (NE) were observed in the experimental group, while 55 cases of CR, 50 cases of 
PR, 5 cases of SD, 2 cases of PD, and 9 cases of NE were observed in the control group. The

Treatment -emergent adverse events were experienced in all subjects of the study. In general, 
the most frequently reported AEs regardless of relationship to the study drug, were fatigue (57.6 
%), anorexia (51.5 %), lymphopenia (42.4 %), cough (39.4 %), dizz iness and dyspnea (36.4 %) 
and nausea and chills (33.3 %) and overall,  the most common treatment -related adverse events

5.38 Study No. YMB -1000 -010 (terminated early, Phase II in NSCLC).  
 
A Phase II, double -blinded, placebo -controlled, multicenter clinical study in patients with 
NSCLC unfit to chemotherapy was performed in 11 clinical sites in Canada, 1 site in United 
States, 1 in Singapore, and 1 in South Korea. No subject was enrolled in the US or Singaporean 
sites. Primary endpoints of the study were to compare overall survival in subject diagnosed with 
locally advanced non -metastatic NSCLC who are unsuitable for radical therapy or metastatic 
NSCLC who required radiotherapy to chest disea se, receiving nimotuzumab with palliative 
radiation vs placebo – palliative radiation alone and secondary endpoint were to assess the local 
and overall response rates of nimotuzumab in combination with palliative radiation vs placebo 
palliative radiation i n patients with NSCLC stage IIB, III and IV, to assess overall clinical benefit, 
to compare progression -free survival and QoL. The study was initiated in March 2009 and was 
early terminated because of the slow inclusion rate of the patients in June 2011.  
Patients were administered 200 mg of nimotuzumab or placebo once a week for 8 weeks. 
Radiotherapy was administered on 3 Gy daily for 5 days a week for 2 weeks to a total of 30 Gy 
(up to an additional 6 Gy in 2 fractions could also be added). If local contr ol was achieved  after 
the initial 8 doses, 200 mg of nimotuzumab or placebo would continue  a weekly regimen until 
disease progression, or unacceptable toxicity.  
A total of 51 patients were administered at least one dose of study drug, 28 patients received 
placebo and 23 nimotuzumab.  
Treatment -emergent adverse events were experienced by all patients in the study. The most 
common adverse events regardless of relationship to the study drug in all patients were fatigue 
(58.8 %), nausea (41.2 %), dyspnea (39.2 %), decreased appetite (37.3 %), dysphagia (35.3 %), 
constipation (33.3 %), and chest pain (33.3 %) and the most common treatment -related adverse  
events were fatigue (45.1 %), nausea (23.5 %), and decreased appetite (21.6 %). There were  
grade 3 or more adverse events reported on 58.8 % of the cases. See Appendix B, Table B -38 
for a complete listing of related AEs.  
A total of 9 deaths were reported during the study, 8 on the placebo arm and 1 on nimotuzumab 
arm. Eight patients on the nimotuzumab arm experienced SAE and 1 died to the SAE. See 
Appendix C, Table C -1 for a complete listing of possibly related SAEs.

This was a Phase II, open label , randomized multicenter study to assess the safety and efficacy 
of nimotuzumab (200 mg) in combination with chemotherapy versus chemotherapy alone in the 
treatment of patients with stage IIIb/IV non -small cell lung cancer.  The primary objective was 
to de termine the objective response rate. Secondary objectives include assessment of overall 
survival and progression free survival. The study was initiated in June 2008 and completed in 
March 2010.  
The study enrolled 110 patients.  Fifty -three (53) patients (12 females and 41 males) with a 
mean age of 58.2 years (range 29 to 73 years) received nimotuzumab and 57 patients (12 females 
and 45 males) with the mean age of 55.6 years (range 32 to 77 years)  were randomized to the 
control group.   
Overall, 43 (81.1%) patients in the nimotuzumab arm reported at least one AE compared to 
47 (82.5 %) patients in the control arm. The majority of nimotuzumab AEs were mild to moderate 
in severity.  The most commonly reported nimotuzumab -related AEs were vo miting (5.7%), 
diarrhea (3.8 %), fatigue (3.8 %), pain (3.8 %) and rash (3.8 %). See Appendix B, Table B -39 
for a listing of AEs.  
Of the 110 subjects enrolled, 15 (28.3 %) patients in the nimotuzumab arm and 26 (45.6 %) 
patients in the control arm reported at least one SAE.  Two SAEs were considered related to 
nimotuzumab: febrile neutropenia and gastroenteritis. See Appendix C, Table C -1 for a list of 
related SAEs.  
In the ITT population, the objective response rate was 54.0% [95% CI: 40.2 – 67.8] in the 
nimotuzumab arm and 34.5 % [95% CI: 22.0 – 47.1] in the control arm; p=0.0448. Median 
overall survival was assessed as 10.1 months [95% CI: 8.1 – 13.6] in the nimotuz umab arm and 
10.4 months [95% CI: 7.4 to 13.7] in the ITT population; p=0.475. Progression free survival was 
also similar between arms, with a result of 4.9 month [95% CI: 4.5 – 6.9] in the nimotuzumab 
arm compared to 4.8 months [95% CI: 2.8 – 5.8] in the control arm.

designed to compare the efficacy of nimotuzumab, cisplatin, vinorelbine, and t horacic radiation 
therapy versus placebo, cisplatin, vinorelbine, and thoracic radiation therapy in patients with 
unresectable locally advanced lung squamous cell carcinoma.  The primary endpoint was overall 
survival (OS), and secondary endpoints were prog ression -free survival (PFS), local control

nimotuzumab at 200 mg dose once a week from d1 for 16 weeks together with chemotherapy  
and radiation . Chemotherapy  consisted of cisplatin (80 mg/m2, d1) and vinorelbine (20 mg/m2,

irradiation of 2 Gy/day (5 days a week) from d1 for 6 weeks . On the control arm , patients were 
administered placebo once a week from day 1 for 16 weeks together with chemotherapy  and 
radiation . Chemotherapy  consisted of cisplatin (80 mg/m2, d1) and vinorelbine (20 mg/m2, d1 
and 8) every 28 days for 4 cycles and radiotherapy consisted of conventionally fractionated  
irradiation of 2 Gy/day (5 days a week) from d1 for 6 weeks. The study was initiated in March 
2013 and prematurely  discontinued on April 2014 according to Independent Data Monitoring

5.42 Study No. IIC RD EC -079 (completed, Brain Metastases from NSCLC).  
 
This was a randomized, multicenter and open -label Phase II clinical trial conducted in patients 
with brain metastases from non -small cell lung cancer. The objectives of the study included 
assessment of disease control rate, duration of response and surviva l. Patients were randomized

Radiotherapy was administered in daily 2 Gy fractions to a total dose of 40 Gy and nimotuzumab 
(200 mg) was administered weekly by intrave nous infusion until disease progression. This study 
was conducted in 5 investigation centers in Cuba. The study initiated in September 2006 and 
completed in December 2008.  
Analysis was performed on 27 patients (20 males/7 females) with a mean age of 56.37 years 
(range 41 to 80) who were enrolled in the study. Of these patients, 14 were evaluable for efficacy 
and 26 were assessed for safety. Fourteen (14) patients were random ized to receive nimotuzumab 
plus WBRT and the remaining 13 received WBRT alone.  
A total of 152 adverse events in 19 patients were reported. From then 120 AEs were associated 
with the treatment arm and 32 AEs to the control arm. Related AEs were reported in 1 patient in 
the nimotuzumab + WBRT group, who experienced mild mucositis. A li st of related AEs is 
provided in Appendix B, Table B -42. No other nimotuzumab -related AEs were reported.  
There were 5 serious adverse events reported in 2 patients during the course of the study. Both 
patients were enrolled in the nimotuzumab + WBRT arm of the study, however, all SAEs were

designed to assess the efficacy of nimotuzumab or racotumomab in comparison to a group of 
patients receiving docetaxel.  
This study was designed with two strata: patients that progressed to the onco especific 
treatment and patients that did not progress . Each stratum  consisted of three groups of treatments 
with nimotuzumab, or racotumomab or docetaxel, randomized as 2:2:1, in favor to the study 
drugs (nimotuzumab and docetaxel).  The primary endpoint was to compare the OS and as 
secondary endpoints were assessed safety and tolerability of PFS and objective response. A total 
of 461 patients were recruited on the study after rece iving initial onco especific treatment. 
According to the study design, for safety and efficacy analysis, only the group of non-progressing  
patients was considered. In this group of non -progressing , a total of 238 patients (143 male / 95 
female) were recruited,  and 93 patients were administered nimotuzumab (55 male / 38 female), 
93 patients received racotumomab (51 male / 42 female) and 52 patients received the control 
docetaxel (37 male / 15 female).  
Nimotuzumab was administered as i.v . infusion at 200 mg dose once a week for 6 weeks and 
then continue with a maintenance phase administered every 2 weeks until unacceptable toxicity. 
Racotumomab was administered intradermal at 1 mg at 5 doses every two weeks and then 
continue with a mainten ance phase administered every 28 days until unacceptable toxicity. The 
control group received docetaxel subcutaneously (75 mg/m2) every three weeks until completing 
6 cycles. Study drugs nimotuzumab and racotumomab were administered beyond progression of 
the disease. The study was  conducted in 65 clinical sites in Cuba. The study  initiated in February 
2013 and completed February 2017.  
In the group of patients treated with nimotuzumab, a total of 1166 AEs were reported, 402

as grade 1 or 2. There were not deaths related to nimotuzumab treatment. See Appendix B, Table 
B-44 for a complete listing of related AEs. The most frequent AEs reported to be related to 
nimotuzumab treatment were myalgia, feve r, headache , nausea and arthralgia. The 99.3% of the 
nimotuzumab related AEs reported were classified as grad e 1 or 2.   
There were 24 subjects (25.8 %) on the nimotuzumab arm reported of having SAEs, and in 
only one of the patients (1.2%) the SAEs were reported to be related to the drug. In the 
nimotuzumab arm a total of 33 SAEs (2.8%) were reported and only one SAEs (0.1%)  was related 
to the drug. A total of 5 deaths (5.4%) were reported during the study in the nimotuzumab arm.

See Appendix C, Table C -1 for a complete listing  of possibly related SAEs.

(Confidential Information )         A single -arm, open label, multi -center Phase II trial was performed to evaluate the activity of 
nimotuzumab as 2nd -line therapy in patients with locally advanced or metastatic pancreatic 
cancer.  The primary endpoint was the remission rate in patients rece iving at least 6 cycles of 
nimotuzumab (200 mg). Secondary endpoints included progression -free survival, safety and 
symptoms  and pain control. This trial was conducted in 6 investigational sites in Germany, and 
it initiated in November 2004 and completed the enrollment in December 2005.  
A total of 56 patients (28 males/28 females) with ages ranging from 44 to 81 were recruited 
for treatment. Due to study -relevant protocol deviations two patients were not eligible for 
efficacy analysis. Most  recruited patients (n=42; 77.8 %) had metastatic pancreatic cancer, 
whereas locally advanced cancer was seen in 7 patients (13.0 %). Five (5) patients (9.3 %) had 
metastatic and locally advanced pancreatic cancer.  
Fifty -four (54) patients were evaluable for safety.  A total of 266 adverse events were included 
in this analysis. The most common adverse events ( 15 % of patients) were (all grades): fatigue 
(24 patients, 44.4 %), fever (10 patients, 18.5 %), pain – abdomen not otherwise specified (10 
patients, 18.5 %) and nausea (9 patients, 16.7 %). Of the 266 reported AEs, 33 were assessed as 
related to nimotuzum ab treatment. A listing of related AEs by grade is shown in Appendix B, 
Table B -45. The most common nimotuzu mab-related events were fever (4 events) as well as 
fatigue, nausea and chills (3 events each).  
Forty (40) SAEs occurred in 20 patients (37.04 %) and 5 SAEs in 4 patients were assessed to 
be related to nimotuzumab. No treatment -related deaths were observed. A listing of SAEs is 
provided in Appendix C, Table C -1.  
The tumor  response status of target and non -target lesions documented for 8 weeks was 
compared to baseline tumor  status according to RECIST.  Of the 54 patients enrolled in the study, 
35 received at least 6 cycles of nimotuzumab and were therefore evaluable for efficacy. Of these 
35 patients, 6 (17.1 %) patients achieved disease stabilization while the remaining 29 (82.8 %) 
patients had progressive disease (PD).    
Patients' progression -free survival was defined as the interval from date of first administration 
of study drug to date of progression or death, whichever occurs first, or to last follow -up 
information (censored observation). Based on the 47 patients evalu able for progression -free 
survival, median PFS was 6.71 weeks (95% CI 6.29 – 7.0 weeks) and the one -year PFS rate was 
10.3 % (95% CI 4.5 – 23.7 %).  
In conclusion, since no remission was observed, no significant effect and no activity with 
respect to its primary objective of remission rate after administration of 6 cycles of nimotuzumab 
could be demonstrated.

5.47 Study No. IIC RD EC -0166 (completed, Phase I V in pancreatic cancer ). 
This was a Phase IV multicenter, open, uncontrolled, non -randomized, clinical trial to evaluate 
the safety and efficacy of CIMAher® (nimotuzumab) in the treatment of patients with locally 
advanced or non -resectable metastatic pancreatic cancer, in either r ecurrent or newly diagnosed 
patients.  
Seventy -one (71) patients treated with nimotuzumab,  and chemotherapy (CT) were included. 
Nimotuzumab 400 mg was administered intravenously (IV) and on an outpatient basis, once a 
week until discontinuation for any of the causes foreseen in the protocol. The CT administered 
during the first year was gemcita bine 1000 mg/m2 (30 min intravenous infusion) on days 1, 8, 
15, followed by a 1 -week rest and repeat the previous regimen until disease progression. The 
protocol was then modified, and CT was selected at t he decision of the investigator, according to 
the NCCN oncology guideline version 3.2017, the availability of the institution and the functional 
capacity of the patient.  
The study foresaw a treatment period of 2 years, to evaluate patients from the clinical point of 
view, and complementary hematological and biochemical examinations were performed prior to 
inclusion and before starting each CT cycle. Every two CT cycles or when disease progression 
was suspected; patients were evaluated through imaging tests (Rx, US and CT). If the patient had 
either an objective response or stable disease, CT continued. If the patient progressed, the CT 
scheme was changed and the treatment c ontinued in combination with nimotuzumab until a new 
progression of the disease. Serious adverse events (AE) with a highly probable, probable and 
possible causality relationship with nimotuzumab were considered as the primary endpoint, and 
the intensity an d causality of the AE, 2 -year overall survival, progression free survival and 
disease control rate (complete, partial or stability of the disease) were considered as secondary 
endpoints. The study initiated in May 2017 and completed in March 2020.  
The safety profile analysis  showed that nimotuzumab  is a safe medication. Most related EAs 
were light and moderate and evolved towards recovery or improvement. No patient died because 
of an adverse event associated with the use of the Nimotuzumab.  The most frequent EAs were 
nausea (10%), anemia (8%), abdominal pain (8%), decay (5%) and vomiting (5%). See 
Appendix B, Table B -47 for a listing of all related adverse events.  
The related EA frequency was 8.1%, and the proportion of nimotuzumab related SAE (very 
likely, likely or possible) was 1.2%.  Twenty -three  percent of the patients presented events 
attributable to the administration of nimotuzumab. The proportion of patients with at least one 
related SAE event was 1.5%, so the hypothesis proposed in the study that the incidence of these 
events was less than 3 5% was fulfilled  (See Appendix C, Table C -1 for a complete listing of 
possibly related SAEs).   
In the overall survival analysis on the ITT population, a median overall survival SV of 9.0 
months (IC95%, 8.36 -15.11) was observed, and 1 -year and 2 -year survival rates of 38.8 and 7.6 
months, respectively. In the subgroup of patients with locally advance d disease, the median 
overall survival was 16.36 months (IC95%, 14.35 -18.38) with 1 -year and 2 -year survival rates 
of 72.2 and 29.2 months, respectively. In patients with metastatic disease, the median overall 
survival was 6.23 months (IC95%, 4.32 -8.13) wi th 1-year and 2 -year survival rates of 18.1 and 
3.0 months, respectively. In this scenario, ITT patients with ECOG greater than or equal to 2, are

disease, a median of 7.6 -month PFS (IC95%, 6.08 -9.90) was achieved, a 1 -year and 2 -year PFS 
rates  of 20.5 and 5.1, respectively. Patients with locally advanced disease and tumor located in 
the body of the pancreas had a risk of death by disease progression 324 times greater than those 
who have tumors located at the head of the pancreas.  
The clinical response showed a complete remission in 3.1% and a partial remission in 15.4% 
of the patients, which accounts for  an objective response in 18.5% of the patients. Disease  control  
was achieved in 43.1 % of the patients of the study. In patients with locally advanced disease, the 
clinical response was evaluated in 18 patients; 8.7% showed complete remission (2 patients) and 
30.4% partial remission (7 patients), which means an objective response of 39.1%. The control 
disease was achieve d in 60.9% of  the patients of this stratum.  In patients with metastatic disease, 
the clinical response was evaluated in 20 patients. There was no complete remission, and 15.0% 
showed objective response (partial remission), achieving a control disease in 33.3% of patients 
of this stratum.  
Three out of the four patients with recurrent disease upon inclusion, had a partial response and 
one stable disease, achieving an objective response in 75% of the patients, and control  disease in 
all these patients. In the PP population, a 4.3 % complete remission and 21.7 % partial remission  
were observed , which contributed to an objective response of 26.1%. Disease control was 
achieved in 60.9% of the study patients.  In patients with locally advanced disease, was obtained 
a 10.0% of complete remission (2 pa tients) and 35.0% of partial remission (7 patients), which 
contributed to an objective response of 45.0%. Disease control was achieved in 70% of the 
patients in this stratum.  In patients with metastatic disease there was no complete remission, and 
the objective response was 11.5% (3 patients with partial remission), achieving a disease control 
in 53.8% of these patients.  
In this study , nimotuzumab was safe and well -tolerated. The proportion of patients with 
related SAE (very likely, probable, or possible) attributable to the use of nimotuzumab was very 
low, and most adverse reactions were  mild and reversible. No patients died due to the 
administration of nimotuzumab.

(Confidential Information )         5.48 Study No. BPL -Nim-PC-1 (completed, Phase III in pancreatic cancer).  
This was a phase III, multicenter, controlled, randomized, double -blind clinical study of 
gemcitabine in combination with nimotuzumab (experimental arm) compared to gemcitabine 
plus placebo (control arm) in patients with K -Ras wild -type locally advanced or  metastatic 
pancreatic cancer. The primary endpoint was to assess the OS of the patients treated with 
nimotuzumab in combination with gemcitabine compared to placebo and gemcitabine alone. The 
secondary endpoints were to determine time to disease progressi on (TTP), progression -free 
survival (PFS), objective response rate (ORR), disease control rate (DCR), clinical benefit 
response (CBR) and safety (according to NCI CTCAE v4.03).  
The total number of patients originally planned to be enrolled was 276, and they were 
randomly assigned at a ratio of 1:1, that is, the experimental group and the control group were 
divided into 138 cases each. Because K -Ras wild -type pancreatic cancer is rare and difficult to 
enroll, and the original sample size was estimated based on the data of the entire pancreatic cancer 
population, a new sample size was calculated, based on the survival data of K -Ras wild -type 
pancreatic cancer in the PCS07 study (Ger many). According to the new criteria, it was estimated 
that 79 subjects and 64 events can meet the statistically sufficient sample size. Therefore, the 
final statistical analysis was performed on the 92 enrolled cases.  
Nimotuzumab injection was administered at a dose of 400 mg, intravenous infusion, with an 
infusion time of 60 minutes. Nimotuzumab treatment was administered once a week until disease 
progression or unacceptable toxicity, or subject requests to withdraw fr om the trial.  Gemcitabine 
was administered at a dose of 1000 mg/m2, intravenous infusion for no less than 30 minutes, 
continuous use for 3 weeks, 1 -week rest (d1, 8, 15; q28 d), every 4 weeks as a cycle, until disease 
progression or intolerable toxicity response, or subject requests to withdraw from the trial. For 
the fi rst treatment, Nimotuzumab/placebo and gemcitabine were administered on the same day, 
Nimotuzumab/placebo was infused first, and gemcitabine was administered 1 hour after the end 
of Nimotuzumab/placebo infusion. Thereafter, nimotuzumab/placebo was treated on the same 
day as gemcitabine, in the same order as before.  
The study was  conducted in 25 investigation centers in China and it initiated in April 2015 
and completed in November 2021.  
For efficacy analysis, a total of 82 subjects were included in the full analysis set (FAS), 
including 41 in the experimental group and 41 in the control group. Fifty -nine cases were 
included in the per -protocol set (PPS), including 28 cases in the experime ntal group and 31 cases 
in the control group. Patients who did not complete the treatment for ≥6 weeks were also included 
in the PPS set for sensitivity analysis, with 37 cases in the experimental group and 36 cases in 
the control group. Ninety cases were included in the safety analysis set (SS set), including 45 
cases in the experimental group and 45 cases in the control group.  
There were 41 cases in the experimental group, the number of events was 36 cases (87.8%), 
and the mOS was 10.9 months . In the control group , there were  41 cases, the n umber of events 
was 40 cases (97.6%), and the mOS was 8.5 months. Compared with the control group, the mOS 
in the nimotuzumab arm was prolonged by 2.4 months, with statistical  clinical significance.  
The overall survival rate of the experimental group compared to  the control group at different 
times (OS Rate) was as follows: the 6 -month OS rate (65.9% vs. 63.4%), 1 -year OS rate (43.6% 
vs. 26.8%), 1.5 -year OS rate (33.4% vs. 17.1%), 2 -year OS rate (20.0% vs. 14.2%), and 3 -year 
OS rate (14.3% vs. 2.8%). The restrict ed mean survival time (RMST) method was used to 
calculate the survival between groups. In the FAS population, adjusted by various stratified 
random factors, a significant benefit in the nimotuz umab arm was observed (HR=0.50, 95% CI 
0.07-0.93, P=0.024). Multiple subgroup analyses showed a significant survival benefit with the 
addition of nimotuzumab, in patients with no prior management of biliary obstruction (11.9 vs. 
8.4 months), HR=0.54), no h istory of surgery (15.8 vs. 6.0 months), HR=0.40) and duration of 
the disease <1 year (9.7 vs. 8.1 months, HR=0.60).
